The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa)
took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and concerns Cambodia. I refer to statements purportedly made by the Minister to journalists in Indonesia last week, including that the Khmer Rouge is unlikely to rejoin the peace process and that options in Cambodia include sanctions against the Khmer Rouge, isolating it in the zones it controls or pulling out of the peacekeeping operation altogether. As these expressions are fundamentally at odds with everything the Minister has said in this chamber regarding the peace process, I ask: what is now the position of the Australian Government? Is the Paris agreement to be revised, and, if so, by what means? Is the United Nations Security Council to revise its mandate for the UN force presently in Cambodia? How does the Minister justify the breach of his undertaking to keep the Parliament fully informed?

—It is a little difficult to keep the Parliament fully informed when the Parliament is not sitting at a time when events are rapidly developing. And events have been rapidly developing over the last few weeks while I and a number of other people intimately concerned with this process have been, and still are, doing our best to work a way through that meets the basic objective—which I take it we all still agree with—which is securing a lasting and durable peace for the people of Cambodia.

para.tab: The premise on which that peace was originally constructed was one of a necessity to create an environment in which free and fair elections could be held and in which an end could be reached to the civil war that had been tearing the country apart—a civil war precipitated and sustained by a Khmer Rouge acting not just on its own resources but with very substantial supply from outside, conspicuously from China; a situation where other external countries were equally giving military support to other players on the ground; and a situation where the United Nations was unable to play any constructive role in assisting the electoral process.

The peace plan that was constructed, built on an Australian initiative, was aimed at creating the conditions where the civil war could end and elections could take place under United Nations auspices. It was necessary to craft a plan of that kind in order to detach the Khmer Rouge from its external sources of supply. It was necessary to craft a plan of that kind in order to take the external countries that were supplying the internal participants and warring factions out of the play.

Without a plan of the kind that we initiated and that was subsequently put into place, we would be now exactly where we were two years ago, with 350,000 people still sitting in border camps, unlike the present situation where nearly 150,000 of them have either voluntarily or under UNHCR auspices come back into Cambodia.

We would have a situation where there would be no reduction in the military activity that was then occurring at very high levels. We would have a situation where there was no prospect of any kind of exercise in electoral testing that could have taken place in any remotely free and fair way. In other words, we would have had a continuation of the civil war. That civil war has come to an end. It has come to an end as a result of the implementation of that peace plan. The United Nations is there; 16,000 troops are there; many electoral officers are there. A civil administration and monitoring operation is in place. A human rights monitoring organisation under UN auspices is in place.

The situation has fundamentally improved, but it is an extraordinarily fragile situation. It is an extraordinarily difficult situation. It is a situation that we knew all along would not proceed to fruition, the result of free and fair elections and a permanent end to civil war, without there being many difficulties along the way. We have struck one of those difficulties. We have run into a significant non-cooperation by the Khmer Rouge.

talk.start.para: —Surprise, surprise!

—`Surprise', says Senator Hill, smiling away at what he thinks will serve him electorally in some way. I find it nothing short of disgusting that there should be this cynicism directed towards this process by Senator Hill who has done nothing constructive at any stage of the whole process to bring it about.

para.tab: We have a situation where there is non-cooperation by the Khmer Rouge. We have a situation where attempts have been made to identify legitimate grounds for concern by the Khmer Rouge—and there were some—about the kind of civil administration that was in place and the kind of playing field that was being maintained by the UN organisation. We have a situation where attempts have been made to meet those legitimate concerns and those attempts are continuing. But very real doubt now exists, not only in my mind but also in the minds of many of the people that I have been talking to over the last two or three weeks—that includes just about all the relevant players and all the relevant Foreign Ministers—as to whether it will be possible for the Khmer Rouge to come back into the settlement in its present operational form.

What do we do about it? Do we sit back and smugly giggle, as Senator Hill does, because there may be some perceived difficulty in this process which may be able to be characterised as some sort of lapse on the part of the good efforts of all those people around the world who have been trying hard to put this process into place; or do we try to work a way through this? What I am trying to do, what everybody else is trying to do, and what I will be doing in Bangkok from tonight for the next three days when I go up there for the APEC meeting and many discussions on this topic on the sidelines to it, is find a way through this which actually works, which is consistent with the original terms of the settlement and which is consistent with the longer term objective, which is to stop a civil war.

There are a number of options that do suggest themselves, and I have indicated publicly what those options are. I have put the options in terms of United Nations sanctions and I have put the options in terms of a quarantining exercise within the existing settlement. That would involve the electoral process continuing and, obviously, some modification of the military strategy, while not seeking for the UN to go into the Khmer Rouge areas which occupy 15 per cent of the landscape and about 200,000 people of the total population of seven million.

There is the option of a UN confrontation of the Khmer Rouge in an attempt to establish a military presence on the ground, and there is the option of complete withdrawal from the situation at this stage. Nobody wants to withdraw from the situation. Everybody wants to see the electoral process maintained. Everybody wants to see the avoidance of a renewal of military conflict. It is my belief that several options are possible, short of UN withdrawal, but nonetheless still premised on the possibility of Khmer Rouge non-cooperation. They are options that can be pursued consistent with the terms of the settlement, and the particular fail-safe mechanisms that are built into that settlement involving negotiations under article 29 and things of that kind. I am not going to spell out in any more detail—

talk.start.para: —You are speculating on the options.

—I have speculated on what the options might be and I have said that we may need to go down that particular track. If we do, it will be consistent with the settlement. If we do, it will still offer a chance, even if Senator Hill is not interested in that chance, of securing a lasting peace for the people of Cambodia.

para.tab: Of course, there are elements of risk involved in this. Any continued presence of the United Nations in a situation where the Khmer Rouge is not cooperating creates the possibility of an outbreak of military conflict at any time. If that outbreak occurs in any systematic way there will be a fundamental problem so far as the retention of UN forces there is concerned, for reasons that have been spelt out on many previous occasions. But it is perfectly possible to believe that this settlement can be held together at the moment.

May I say finally that the concept of quarantining the Khmer Rouge in the context that I have described is a very different concept from that of seeking to isolate the Khmer Rouge back in the period 18 months to two years ago, before we had a settlement, when the Khmer Rouge were still inextricably connected to China and were still with those sources of overt external support. If Senator Hill cannot understand the difference between an exercise in quarantining the Khmer Rouge now against all the background of a successful UN plan, which has detached the Khmer Rouge from the source of its external supply, and the kind of situation which existed previously, then Senator Hill is no longer simply guilty of malice, as I have always kindly assumed; he is guilty of overt and comprehensive stupidity as well.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister seen reports that Mitsubishi Motors says it will abandon plans to invest $600m in Australia if this country were to adopt a zero tariff policy for the car industry? Has the Minister had examined claims that a policy of zero tariffs, combined with micro-economic reform, would increase employment in the industry by 5,000? Can the Minister comment on the outlook for the industry generally, and employment in particular, under the Government's policy?

—Senator Foreman asked me about the Mitsubishi statement reported in the Adelaide
Advertiser
today. I checked on that statement. Mitsubishi was approached by the Adelaide
Advertiser
to see what its views were about this issue. In response to that, Mitsubishi made the announcement which is reported in that paper today. That announcement means that the company would walk away from plans for a new $100m engine plant. It would abandon plans to make the next generation Magna in Australia. It would switch to imports and it would drastically cut its current work force of 4,200.

para.tab:
Senator Chapman interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Senator Chapman should go back to Adelaide and tell that to the electorate. If the honourable senator wants to identify himself in here, we will do it for him over there.

para.tab: This would be the first instalment in the price Australia would have to pay for the zero tariff policies of the Opposition. Of course, other investment decisions which have to be made in the next 12 to 18 months would be threatened by the Opposition's policies. The companies include Ford, General Motors and Toyota, which is unhappy with its significant investment in Altona.

All this potential damage to Australian industry and Australian employment comes from the mindless ideological obsessions of the Leader of the Opposition and Mr McLachlan, the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce. What we have seen is a victory for blind ideology over rationality. No amount of facts which conflict with that ideology will in any sense be persuasive.

There has been a long period of negotiations between the automotive companies and the Opposition in trying to resolve these issues. And still Mr McLachlan does not understand. He does not understand that this is a volume dependent industry and that volumes are crucial to the success of the industry in this country. He is not able to understand that fact.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I would draw your attention to standing order 73(4) which says that in answering a question, a Minister shall not debate it. I would further draw your attention to your ruling of 26 November 1991 when you said that a Minister may develop an argument but he may not debate the question. I would ask you to uphold standing order 73(4) and your ruling. He is clearly now past developing an argument and is debating the question.

—Order! I think at this stage the Minister is only developing an argument. The Chair, traditionally, is tolerant of the first question from the Leader of the Opposition and the first question to the Leader of the Government—in terms of time.
—Mr President, on the point of order: I ask for clarification of when you deem the Minister to have finished developing an argument and to be starting to debate the question.

—Speaking to the point of order, Mr President: this side of the House is getting a bit tired of this selective indignation. We have had only two examples of Opposition frontbenchers getting dorothies sent to them. They both spoke at great length and we all waited with breathless expectation for Senator Bishop to raise a point of order—and not a word was heard. It is what is called selective indignation. Mr President, she is seeking from you partisan interpretation of the Standing Orders, and I think you should continue with your non-partisan one.

—On this question of employment in the motor vehicle industry in Australia, on 27 August Mr McLachlan, the Opposition's spokesman on these issues, was interviewed in the
Australian
, and in order to pursue the argument about protection, which he wants to do because he is a delegate from the 1970 vintage Farmers Federation here, he said—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Again I would draw your attention to standing order 73(4). I do so on the basis that we now also have the Minister debating the question in terms of explaining what Opposition policy is according to John Button. Mr President, I would direct your attention to another of your rulings when you said that the Minister may only answer the question as it relates to his portfolio and not to Opposition policy. There are two points on which I would ask you now to uphold your own rulings. The Minister has clearly gone beyond even your point of tolerance.
—On the point of order, Mr President, I was asked a question about policy for the motor vehicle industry—

—Particularly policy which adversely affected the interests of companies such as Mitsubishi. That is the question I am answering. Senator Hill keeps interjecting about job losses. The Opposition's shadow Minister for industry, in support of his argument for zero protection, says, `Look at the unprotected food processing industry: 12,500 new jobs created in the last two years'. That is a total invention; that is a lie and an invention.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I do not know where Senator Button finished his speech on the point of order or whether he is now continuing to answer the question. I am waiting for your ruling on the point of order.

—Order! I do not think at this stage the Minister is debating the question, and I make the point again to both sides of the chamber that a lot of the long answers are not helped by constant interjections from both sides which are then answered by the Minister.

—The issue of employment is of vital concern to this chamber. Senator Hill keeps interjecting about it. On the issue of employment in manufacturing industry, the Opposition spokesman has invented figures about this issue. That is what he has done, and the Leader of the Opposition is no better. Those opposite talk about 2 million jobs being created with
Fightback
. The first 12,500 are mythical; they do not exist. The second 5,000 are mythical; they do not exist.

para.tab:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order!
—It's a disgrace, Mr President. What are you going to do about it?
—Order! Repeatedly in the last session of the Parliament, I said that calling senators a disgrace, from both sides of the chamber, was out of order. I want that ruling to be adhered to.
—What is going on is a disgrace, Mr President, and what are you going to do about it?
—Order!
—It is a disgrace! You are destroying Question Time.

—I was asked a question about Mitsubishi and its view of the world and I will answer it if this windbag, this refugee from Patrick Partners, will stop interrupting me. In the past two or three days, the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, has entered the lists, promising 5,000 new jobs in the automotive industry. He has promised us more jobs and cheaper cars. Mitsubishi exploded that sort of claim in its statement reported in the Adelaide
Advertiser
this morning. Dr Hewson claims that the Industry Commission backs him up. It is a total misreading of a report of the Industry Commission. The table on the car industry is taken from the report of 1989-90.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I put to you that there is no way that what the Minister is doing can be interpreted as other than conducting a debate. It is a debate on Fightback. There are appropriate times for that but now is not the appropriate time. This is the occasion that the Minister answers questions relating to his administration, his portfolio; instead, he is abusing Question Time and using it for other purposes. I ask you to bring the Minister to order.
—Order! The Minister's answer is becoming too long. It is obviously not being helped by repeated interjections.
—If it were not so long, there would be no interjections.
—Order! I am not being helped by you, Senator Baume. I ask the Minister to conclude the answer.

—I am bringing the answer to a conclusion now. In relation to the employment issue, the only new jobs that will be created in the motor vehicle industry by the Opposition's policies are 5,000 new jobs in Japan. That is where they will be created—not in Australia. This Government has a program for the automotive industry. We have been totally up-front with both the industry and the unions about employment. We have agreed that there will be reductions in employment over time, but not of the order which the Opposition policy proposes. The problem is that those opposite have been misled by a textbook conceived by an academic—a yuppie academic. They have a textbook to which the real world does not fit. The real world has to change, not the textbook.

para.tab:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! I am asking the Minister to conclude.
—I have finished.

—I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to his outrageous attempt, with the connivance of the Australian Democrats, to curtail freedom of speech by banning political advertising—a cynically motivated strategy to prop up the Labor Party's ailing finances which has now been thrown out by the High Court. I ask the Minister why he wasted millions of dollars of taxpayers' money by not accepting the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and the widespread opinion of constitutional experts, such as Professor Leslie Zines, who said that the legislation was unconstitutional. I ask the Minister to now table: firstly, the preliminary advice from the Attorney-General which formed the basis of his submission to Cabinet on 19 March 1991; secondly, subsequent advice from the Solicitor-General, Dr Gavan Griffith, of 25 March 1991; and, thirdly, advice provided by the Chief General Counsel in relation to the regulations.
—Senator Parer talks about an outrageous proposal. I remind this place—
—Answer the question!
—Senator Parer will get the answer; he will get a full answer. The proposal that was put up by the Government came—

para.tab:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I do not know whether those opposite want an answer. If they do, they will keep quiet and they will get one; but if they behave like a rabble, maybe I should not dignify them with an answer.

para.tab:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Maybe they should have left you at the bottom of the harbour where they found you.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask the Minister to withdraw that remark as it is unparliamentary.
—I am not so sure it is unparliamentary.
—I think you are right, Mr President.
—Order! I do not think it is unparliamentary, but again, there have been a number of comments about people across the chamber and I ask for them to cease.

—Mr President, I was about to say that the proposal put up by the Government was not outrageous. It came after a long process in this place and in the other place. Government and some parts of the political process other than this Government were, and are, concerned about the cost of campaigning; they were also concerned about the disclosure of campaign resources and funds.

para.tab: As a consequence of that, we had a number of committees in this place look at proposals to cover this area. One committee that looked at this was the Joint Standing Committee which reported in 1989. It advised the Government to take measures to do two things: firstly, to cut back on the costs of advertising by providing a free time proposal, which was something like what finished up coming out of this place; and, secondly, to have full disclosure of party finances.

In respect of the second point, it should be remembered that this Government introduced legislation—that legislation still stands—that provides for full and total disclosure. That was legislation that we had to drag the Opposition to accept. What stands from this process is that that part of the legislation will stay in place and work towards keeping the system clean.

We are told by the Liberals in Queensland—or should I quote Wal Murray and call them the idiot Liberals in Queensland?—that we are rorting the system. There is no rorting of the system. The word `connivance' has been used in terms of the position of the Australian Democrats; it is totally inappropriate. They came to their position after a long debate; a position which was somewhere close to the Government but independent of the Government. There was no connivance.

I have been asked to table advice. I want to say a couple of things about that. Firstly, Mr President, the result was not just a surprise for those of us on this side but, I put it to you, a surprise in its totality to those on the other side.

talk.start.para: —We predicted it.

—They may have predicted it in terms of part of the legislation, but they did not predict it in terms of the whole lot. There is a standing procedure in respect of legal advice provided to government—that is, that government does not table such advice—and we are not going to deviate from that procedure this time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and concerns the appalling massacre which occurred yesterday in Ciskei, South Africa. Can the Minister provide any further details on how and why the massacre occurred? In particular, has he any details on the involvement of the South African security forces in the massacre? What has been the response of the South African Government? Is its response satisfactory? Finally, what action has the Australian Government taken in response to this appalling massacre of innocent people?

—Mr President, I know that all Australians will be sickened by the deliberate, calculated massacre of peaceful demonstrators which occurred at the hands of the Ciskei defence forces yesterday. Eye witness accounts, which have been confirmed by television footage, show that the Ciskei defence forces fired indiscriminately on peaceful demonstrators who were not in any way acting violently at the time or threatening violence. I say immediately that it is very difficult to accept the statement made by South African Ambassador Tothill this morning on ABC radio that the ANC should be regarded as sharing the responsibility for its provocation of the massacre. What the ANC was clearly doing was exercising its peaceful right to demonstrate in a democratic and peaceful manner.

para.tab: It is about time the South African Government and its representatives showed some sensitive appreciation of what the democratic process is all about. The Ciskei massacre now has to be added to that long and ever growing litany of tragedies, including Sharpeville and Boipatong, which are the direct and inevitable by-product of the repressive apartheid system.

As I said myself this morning, the tragedy shows how the apartheid system has corrupted and perverted so much of the institutional structure of South Africa and created the situation we are now seeing of the determination of those who have benefited from the system to cling on to their power and their privilege, undemocratically secured by them, at all costs.

There have been reports that the South African defence force units were in the area at the time of the massacre. We do not yet have any firm information about their role other than they do not appear to have been in any way participating directly in the shooting which occurred. It has to be said, however, that the massacre was committed by the Ciskei defence forces. The Ciskei Government is, of course, an entirely artificial product of the apartheid system, propped up by the South African Government, not recognised by any other government other than the South African Government, and which has an appalling record for abusing human rights. Certainly under international law the South African Government has to assume responsibility for the actions of the Ciskei authorities. We are of course looking to the South African Government to quickly take action to ensure that those responsible for the killings are brought to justice.

It is too early to assess whether the presence of international observers could have averted this massacre. There were observers present from the national peace committees, but one lesson from it is the necessity to have an effective international presence in South Africa as soon as possible. We as an Australian government are firmly committed to assisting with the peace process in South Africa. I and the Prime Minister have made it clear that we are ready to participate in any international observer team under United Nations or Commonwealth auspices that may be sent to South Africa. Those United Nations observers are to take up their task this week and we are presently discussing with the Commonwealth what we might appropriately do by way of a supplementary exercise in that respect coordinated with it.

Finally, nobody knows at this stage what the implications of the massacre are going to be for the future of the constitutional talks. One can only hope that this will be the shock that brings the parties back to the negotiating table and not the disaster that sends the whole system plunging once again into a downward spiral. It is a very unhappy situation. It is not one that could give anyone cause for any comfort. We can only hope and pray that some sanity will emerge out of this disaster.

talk.start.para: —Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate agree that a so-called friend prepared to bankrupt Australian wheat farmers for domestic electioneering purposes can no longer be treated as a friend? Is the Government prepared to tell President Bush that unless the proposed expansion of wheat export subsidies is abandoned the Australian Government will, firstly, withdraw the invitation to the United States defence forces to use the Delamere firing range; secondly, issue a notice to quit other shared facilities, including Pine Gap and Nurrungar; thirdly, consider the United States action on wheat as putting in jeopardy United States requests for Australian cooperation on air traffic routes; and, fourthly, participate in concerted action with Canada and Argentina designed to get the United States to implement the reductions in trade barriers it preaches to others?

—Senator Spindler is inviting trade retaliation of a most unusual kind. I will deal with the elements of his proposed retaliation in a minute. The Government has deplored the US EEP initiative which threatens a further escalation in the wheat subsidies war between the United States and the European Community with consequent damage to new markets for Australian farmers.
—And old markets.

—And old markets. Yes, Senator Panizza, that is true. People have noticed, I guess, that President Bush made a special mention of Australia in his announcement when he talked of safeguarding the interests of non-subsidising exporters. But I must say at this stage that it is not clear what that means and this Government will continue to press the United States to adhere to the latest initiative in implementing its specific markets through the coming year.

para.tab: We have also decided now to take up our concerns in the GATT because we are fed up with being caught in the cross-fire of this subsidies war between the United States and the EC.

talk.start.para: —Six years and you haven't done anything.

—Senator Boswell should recognise first of all that, as his leader says, in relation to wheat, the United States is the major trade enemy of Australia. The fact of the matter is that for a very long time while Senator Boswell has been sitting here the trade imbalance between the United States and Australia has run enormously in favour of the United States. At the same time as his leader in the National Party is talking about the major trade enemy being the United States, Dr Hewson is writing to the President suggesting we join the North American Free Trade Association. Really, they ought to have a bit of a chat amongst themselves about what is going on and what coalition policy on these issues is, because the two are mutually exclusive.

para.tab: In respect of Senator Spindler's particular form of punishment of the United States, which presumably would be handed out by a Democrat Government if we ever had one in Australia, we are asked to withdraw the invitation to the US defence forces to use the Delamere firing range and to issue a notice to quit in relation to Pine Gap and Nurrungar. I am advised by the Defence Minister that, in terms of the relationship which exists, if anything would be cutting off our nose to spite our face, those two pieces of retaliation would be, because Australia is a greater beneficiary of the use of those facilities than the United States.

Senator Spindler also asked me what we would do about negotiations relating to international air routes with the United States—another form of punishment which I believe would rebound on the country which sought to impose it. It is a matter which he ought to take up in detail with my colleague Senator Collins, but I do not think he would find us particularly to be beneficiaries of that proposed form of retaliation.

Senator Spindler also suggested that we take concerted action with Canada and Argentina in relation to reductions in trade barriers to be implemented by the United States. As I understand it, the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Mr Kerin, has already been in touch with the Canadian Government about this issue; I do not think anything has happened in respect of Argentina. But, in respect of the approach which the Commonwealth Government in Australia has taken to GATT, Mr Kerin has already asked the Canadians, members of NAFTA, to participate in that approach to the GATT. That seems to us to be the best action which can be taken which has the possibility of some practical value. There is a lot of heat in this issue, but it is also important that we have a little light.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We have heard the Minister give us an account of the softly, softly approach that the Government seems to be taking on this issue. I would like the Minister to take this question on notice and to tell us what possible benefits we are receiving from the US defence forces sharing our facilities and not even telling us what they are doing. Clearly, that is something the United States wants. Surely we can use that as a lever. If that is not enough, could the Minister outline what we can use, in his view, as a lever to protect our wheat farmers?

—I do not want Senator Spindler to be led down the garden path by the heat which has been engendered over this issue. We have to recognise here that the Uruguay Round is still alive and discussions will be continued between September and November. Whether they will succeed or not, I do not know. But, in that context, we have to recognise that the Uruguay Round is still alive and that discussions will continue there about a whole range of matters which embrace the particular issue about which Senator Spindler is concerned.

para.tab: In so far as the question of benefits of the defence facilities to the Americans and to the Australians is concerned, I suggest that the honourable senator direct that question to Senator Ray in due course.

talk.start.para: —I direct a question to Senator Cook in his capacity as Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Have the Federal Government and the stevedoring industry recently agreed on plans for more employees to leave the waterfront under voluntary redundancy arrangements? If so, what does this agreement mean for increased productivity and efficiency of the waterfront under the Government's program of micro-economic reform?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —Quite a bit. I saw Tim Fischer on television last night give a sterling performance, indicating that he would get some more efficiencies out of the waterfront. The news is that we have got the efficiencies out of the waterfront. The changes that I announced last week are a world model for obtaining real efficiency gains in an industry like the waterfront, without there being any massive disputation or disruption. These gains have produced startlingly higher productivity figures, quicker ship turnaround times and more efficient loading speeds with a reduced manning complement, without there being the disruption, confrontation and disputation that the Opposition's policies all promise to wreak on the Australian waterfront. It ought to be acknowledged that my ministerial colleague Senator Bob Collins had a large hand in achieving this, and credit should be paid where it is due.

para.tab: Last week we concluded, through the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority and the stevedoring companies, talks which mean that 900 waterside workers will now leave the industry, accepting voluntary redundancy. This will exceed the levels we originally planned when we embarked on waterfront reform. It will mean that 5,000 will have left the industry since we commenced the reform process, a cut of some 56 per cent in the work force. A significant productivity boost has been set in train.

With the recovery that we are now moving towards, we can expect that there will not be a need within the terms of the plan to increase the number of people employed on the waterfront because the efficiency gains will pick up the extra capacity demanded by the waterfront with the growth in Australian exports that will occur throughout the recovery period. Employee productivity on the Australian waterfront has doubled since we embarked on the waterfront reform program. There has been a 50 per cent increase in the average rate of the handling of containers on the waterfront. There has been a 40 per cent cut in the turnaround time on ships in port in Australia. There is a greater saving in dockside efficiency because of those gains.

I was talking recently to the representative of an international shipping company who said that in the old days—that is, obviously in the days of the coalition Government—companies knew what time the ships would arrive in Australia but they were never quite sure when they would depart. Now they know when they will arrive and when they will depart.

Stevedoring industry charges have declined by between 20 and 25 per cent over the past 18 months in contracts written for new business and in contracts that have been renewed. This was confirmed by the Prices Surveillance Authority in its report under the signature of its Chairman, Professor Fels, just the other week. He identified that there are those significant savings. In his view the problem is that in not all cases has the full measure of those savings been passed on to the shippers.

talk.start.para: —The New South Wales port authority—that's who.

—As well as that, as my colleague Senator Collins interjects, the Sydney Ports Authority is regarded by the New South Wales Government—which, for the record, is a coalition government—as a taxation office. It recoups $35m out of the New South Wales harbour authority as a tax on exports and as a tax on imports into this country, because that is what it is.

para.tab: This is a remarkable achievement. It also means that a levy for supporting the transitional labour list will be abolished. That will be a saving of some $24m on shippers.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Standing order 184 entitles you to maintain order in the Senate. I notice that on frequent occasions you have drawn attention to the length of questions and your desire to see order maintained in this place by a decent number of questions being asked on any day. I put it to you that this is a prefabricated question with a prefabricated answer that could have been put in a press release. It is simply taking up the time of the Senate to the exclusion of questions from this side, that side and the Australian Democrats. Under that standing order, I ask you to ask the Minister to sit down.
—In reply to the point of order, I think that so far today there has been a record low number of questions. I would ask the Minister to conclude.

—I was coming to the end and I will conclude. With the amount of commentary about waterfront reform in this chamber, I would have thought a few facts about the real and significant changes that have been made would illuminate the discussion and help remove that veil of prejudice that shields the Opposition's eyes from the real changes in the Australian community. As I said when I started, this reform has been achieved smoothly without disputation. That stands in sharp contrast to the proposal of the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, to put the troops on the Australian waterfront and invite further conflict and bloodshed.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given that the Government has a bond selling program this financial year in excess of $18 billion, that the current account deficit is already rising ominously, that the Australian dollar has suffered a major fall in recent months, that both short and long term interest rates have already commenced to rise in the markets, and that two of Australia's major commercial banks have already lifted interest rates, will the Minister, on behalf of the Government, rule out any increase in official interest rates before the next election?

—I am not going to depart from my previous practice of not speculating about interest rates. Both the National Australia Bank and the State Bank of New South Wales, the two banks to which I believe Senator Short refers, have had a very small increase in interest rates and prime business rates—in the case of NAB by 0.2 per cent. That puts its rates slightly above the rates charged by other banks. Both the National Australia Bank and the State Bank of New South Wales have said that there is no long term trend towards higher home loan rates and that banks occasionally adjust their rates for commercial reasons. The National Australia Bank went on to say that its action related to its commercial competitive strategy and its behaviour does not reflect a change in government monetary policy. That is what the bank itself said. I do not want to speculate on interest rates, but that is the bank's view.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In that answer the Minister seems to have been totally unaware that both long and short term rates have risen in the market. He seems to be unaware that there is pressure on rates through pressure on the dollar and other reasons. I remind him that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have constantly speculated about interest rates in recent weeks, and Senator Button himself has been speculating on the value of the dollar. Therefore, I repeat the question: will the Minister rule out any increase in official interest rates before the next election?

—Apart from one minor correction in which I did not speculate about the value of the dollar, I was answering a question in relation to the level of Australia's overseas debt and, in that context, I referred to remarks made by an economist.
—Yes, you said the dollar would fall further.

—Senator Alston can say what he likes about that, but the point is that Senator Short, by asking a supplementary question, will not get me to do something which I declined to do in the answer to the original question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General and relates to communication No. 488 of 1990 to a working party of the United Nations Human Rights Committee made under the first optional protocol of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That communication claimed that Tasmanian law criminalising all forms of homosexual activity in private between consenting adult males violates articles of the International Covenant. Is the Minister aware of this communication? Is the Minister aware of a request from the working party for information from the Australian Government regarding the admissibility of the communication? What were the reasons for the Government's failure to meet the UN Human Rights Committee's initial deadline for a response on 14 July and why did the Government ask for a second extension for its response? Are the Government's requests for extra time related to its current deliberations on the issue of homosexuals in the Australian defence forces?

—I am aware that a Tasmanian has made a complaint to the United Nations Human Rights Committee under the first optional protocol of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The complaint, as Senator Powell indicates, alleges that Tasmania's anti-homosexual laws violate the International Covenant. As complaints to the United Nations Human Rights Committee are confidential and the Committee expects both parties to a complaint to refrain from giving publicity to it while it is under consideration by the Committee, it is not possible to go into the details of that Tasmanian complaint.

para.tab:
It is true that a working group of the Committee requested the Australian Government to provide specific information on the admissibility of the communication no later than 14 July 1992, and the Government has since requested extensions to that deadline.
The Centre for Human Rights has advised that it is routine to give governments time for submissions to be lodged, and it is expected that the Government's submission to the Committee will be lodged in the very near future. It is, of course, a submission in relation to the questions of admissibility and jurisdiction and not the merits of the complaint.

The Government sought extension of the deadline for the following reasons: the Department received the communication from the Human Rights Committee on 27 May 1992 and immediately sought the views of the Tasmanian Government, which were received on 29 June. Clearly, in cases such as this involving State laws, it is both necessary and appropriate to consult with the government concerned. The Government takes the complaint seriously, being the first to the Committee. The Attorney-General and, of course, the Department believe that it is most important to fully explore and carefully consider all the jurisdictional issues concerned. As it was not possible to do this in the time provided by the Committee, the Department contacted the human rights centre in Geneva and the centre indicated that the extended time frame was satisfactory.

The Government expects to respond on the admissibility questions in the very near future so that the admissibility issue will be considered at the next meeting of the Human Rights Committee in October. This delay will result in no adverse consequences for either the author of the communication or the Government. The Government's requests for extra time are completely unrelated to the current consideration of the issue of homosexuals in the Australian Defence Force.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that the Tricontinental Royal Commission has concluded that the Reserve Bank of Australia must be partly held to blame for the collapse of Tricontinental, saying that it `failed to perform its role adequately'? Is it a fact that the ex-Premier of Victoria, Mr Cain, stated to the Royal Commission that he believed that the Reserve Bank had a responsibility to `maintain the integrity of the system'? I point out that in 1986 the State Bank of Victoria entered into a voluntary agreement with the Reserve Bank to observe its prudential guidelines, an arrangement which the report says conferred monitoring and financial control responsibilities on the Reserve Bank. Is it not also a fact that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has repeatedly told the Parliament that he did not believe that the Reserve Bank was in any way responsible? I ask the Minister: who is correct, the Royal Commission or the Prime Minister?
—I am advised that the Reserve Bank has not yet seen a copy of the Royal Commission's final report.
—That is because it was only given to two newspapers instead of being released properly.

—It has not had the capacity to analyse it. On the basis of some reports which have been referred to by Senator Alston in his interjection, I want to say a couple of things. First, at the time the Reserve Bank had no responsibility, statutory or otherwise, to supervise Tricontinental, which was not a bank. Secondly, the Reserve Bank had no statutory responsibility to supervise Tricontinental's owner, the State Bank of Victoria, but the State Bank of Victoria had agreed to comply with the RBA's supervisory requirements on banks. One element of banks' supervision is a set of guidelines designed to minimise the likelihood that the bank might be damaged by problems arising in a subsidiary. These guidelines place a clear onus on a bank's management to oversee the sound operation of any subsidiary financial institutions.

para.tab: I do not recall precisely what the Prime Minister said when he was Treasurer about the role and function of the Reserve Bank in relation to this matter. What I have just said is consistent with what Senator Lewis told me the Prime Minister was alleged to have said. We can all benefit from the wisdom of hindsight. It was only five years ago that Senator Lewis's leader, Dr Hewson, nominated Tim Marcus Clark and Bill Moyle of the State Bank of Victoria as people who we would like to see as potential Governors of the Reserve Bank.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the response of the Australian Government to suggestions that Australia should seek unilaterally to join the North American Free Trade Association? Further, is the criticism of the Australian Government which claims that our trade policy has placed all its eggs in the Asia basket informed, fair or reasonable? Finally, is there anything to be distilled from the confusion in Opposition thinking on foreign and trade policy, including Japan bashing, which recommends itself to the Australian Government sufficiently to cause trade policy to be either recast or reviewed?

—There is nothing that has been said this week on trade policy by the Opposition, in all its inconsistency, immaturity and eccentricity, which would in any way lead the Australian Government to recast or review its trade policy. There is probably no clearer example of that immaturity at work than the performance of Dr Hewson on the question of Australia joining NAFTA—at the same time as he is hurling abuse at the United States for its contributions to trade policy. It is a classic example of policy made on the run without any reference to the costs and benefits that are involved.
—What about Dawkins?

—I will tell Senator Alston about Mr Dawkins in a minute if he would just be quiet. Dr Hewson says that the only reason Australia should join NAFTA—or the real reason—is to obtain compensatory concessions to offset the damage that has been done to our wheat growers through EEP. But there is simply no magic key for Australia in NAFTA that would generate those kinds of concessions. The only big returns that Australia could reasonably expect to get out of a free trade agreement with the United States or the NAFTA group of countries would be if we could get major concessions on major trade items such as sugar, beef and dairy products.

para.tab: But there is absolutely no reason to believe that United States special interest lobbies, which are so formidable in this area of managed trade, would yield in those areas. They would want to retain the very tight restrictions that presently exist in all those areas. The United States-Canada FTA and now the new NAFTA agreement itself do not restrain EEP or US export subsidies. Neither Mexico nor Canada got what they wanted from the agreement in those sensitive managed trade areas. Where they do appear to obtain concessions—and there are a few, obviously, in the agreement—these will equally take a very long time to impact.
The second point to make is that even if we did manage to extract some concessions in those particular crucial areas, even if it can be assumed in that respect—

talk.start.para: —Why did Dawkins think it was such a good idea?

—I will come to that. Even in that respect, if it were the case that NAFTA were to deliver some benefits to us, we would have to make enormous policy concessions in return. Among the concessions we would have to anticipate would be the elimination of tariffs for NAFTA countries in our own sensitive industry sectors like textiles, clothing and footwear, and, of course, cars. It would involve clearly the removal of local content restrictions on television, broadcasting and advertising; it would involve changes in the foreign investment area; and it would involve dismantling of the Government's information industry policy. We know that because these are the sorts of things that the United States has already very squarely and explicitly put on the agenda.

para.tab: We know what the Opposition is going to do, if it gets the chance, to the Australian car industry. That would just be done even more quickly and at a more accelerated rate if we were to lurch into membership of NAFTA on the kind of conditions that the Opposition seems to be anticipating.

There is a bigger question also about all this which goes to the larger issues of Australian trade policy. The stated intention of the Bush Administration so far as NAFTA is concerned is to build a free trade area in both the Americas—the whole of the North and South American continents. There is no suggestion that the United States has been thinking about extending NAFTA outside the Americas. All the indications are that it is a block building exercise looking south.

Australia's prosperity depends upon our having liberal access into our own crucial Asian markets. Anyone who does not understand the balance of significance between the Asian markets and the American ones needs to think again because 60 per cent of our exports are now going into Asia and only 9.5 per cent to the United States. If we want to include all three NAFTA countries together, the grand total is 11.2 per cent. That is the kind of concept we are starting with at the moment—60 per cent of our exports going into south-east and north-east Asia; just over 11 per cent into the NAFTA area.

As I say, Australia's prosperity depends on keeping a free and open Asian trading area and Asia's prosperity, on which we depend, depends on keeping a free and open trading regime operating between it and the United States. The point about the NAFTA exercise is that if Australia were to sign on to it this would very greatly further the risk of global trade fragmentation and, in particular, the very fragmentation that we want to avoid so far as the Pacific area as a whole is concerned.

What we are about with APEC—Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation—is uniting the Pacific. Australia expressed all sorts of reservations about the Malaysian EAEC concept as an idea, not just because it excluded Australia and New Zealand but because it excluded the United States and Canada as well and because, as such, it risked accelerating the process of subregional block building and increasing the process of global trade fragmentation.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The Government has so abused Question Time today that the Opposition has asked only four questions. Yet, the Minister is prepared to go on breaching Standing Orders by debating this issue rather than answering the question. It is now after 3 p.m. He should put down a statement and let us have a trade debate. Let us go through what John Dawkins said, not only this year but in 1980, 1987 and 1991. Let us see what the now Treasurer's views were about joining NAFTA and why he was recommending that the Australian Government should in fact join that organisation. Mr President, I ask you to sit the Minister down. I will then move that Question Time might continue.
—Order! I would ask the Minister to conclude the answer. It is quite a long one. I believe that Question Time is going to continue.

—The point, Mr President, is that for all the difficulties we had about the EAEC concept, Australia joining NAFTA involves the risk of creating an EAEC by default and fundamentally making the goals of the APEC regime that much more difficult.

para.tab: I have been invited to talk about Mr Dawkins' contribution to this debate. I am happy to extend my answer for a minute to deal with that interjection by saying just this: it was perfectly sensible for John Dawkins, as he did six years ago, to commission a study, the first Snape report, on the possible advantages to Australia of entering into a free trade agreement with the United States. It was perfectly sensible of the Government to keep, as it has been doing, that particular possibility under review.

But the point is this: the first Snape report made it clear that it could not be assumed there would be any advantages for Australia in such an agreement for all the reasons that I have just spelt out. The second Snape report, which is now under preparation and of which Mr Dawkins is now aware, which he was not last week, makes exactly the same point—he will make the point if those opposite ask him; maybe they have—and shows that Australia's best approach—

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have asked the Minister to finish his answer; he has refused to do that. I ask you to sit him down so that Question Time can proceed.
—Order! Senator Evans, will you please conclude the answer.
—Mr President, I am responding to specific interjections that I had through the whole course of my answer, and I am making just this particular point.
—Order! Senator Evans, please conclude.

—I am concluding with this sentence, Mr President, if I may. The second Snape report makes the point that Australia's overwhelmingly best approach is to continue to work through the multilateral route with trade liberalisation achieved through the Uruguay Round and through APEC; that these provide much better options for Australia than trying in a half-baked, immature, erratic and eccentric way to join a trade bloc that we have not been asked to join.
—My question is also addressed to—

—Mr President, I would normally ask that further questions be placed on notice at this stage. I do not intend to do so for a quarter of an hour. Senator Evans has to leave. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Evans should be directed to Senator Ray from now on.

—Mr President, I must protest. We have an absolutely critical position in the wheat area, and the man who is in charge of it walks out of the Senate and abandons his position. Anyhow, I do not expect Senator Ray will be able to answer this question, not because he is incompetent but because he will not have the experience. My question was to be addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, who has just abandoned the chamber. In view of the effect on future Australian trade following the US Government lifting its EEP program by $1.4 billion on all its export wheat sales and the likelihood of a further disastrous trade war with the EC with dire consequences for the Australian wheat industry, and considering the development this year of free trade blocs between six Asian nations and the NAFTA agreement between the US, Canada and Mexico creating the world's largest trading bloc with serious threats to our sugar, beef and canned fruit exports, I ask the Minister for the army: has the Government assessed the damage to the Australian grains industry resulting from the increase in the US EEP subsidy scheme? What further action will the Australian Government take now that most other trading nations are safely part of a large trading bloc or will the Government continue with its policy of relying solely on resolution of the GATT Uruguay Round due for its sixth birthday?

—The first thing I am not going to do is repeat Senator Evans's eight-minute answer which basically covered in totality the subject matter raised by Senator Boswell. Australia is not in a position where it can force changes on either European or US behaviour other than through the GATT Round. I think we should acknowledge that we as a country and as a leader of the Cairns Group have been at the forefront in leading the way to try to end these corrupt trade practices. We can work through the international community and try to achieve that or we can run around the bush making inconsistent, loud and obnoxious statements which are contradictory and achieve absolutely nothing more than trying to suck in those who are most damaged in this situation.

para.tab: I find a bit pathetic some of the statements I have seen on this subject. Nothing could be more pathetic, in my history of politics, than the 25-minute grilling that your leader got last night on television. I felt sorry for him. He bled to death nationally; he died nationally. He did not even know about the exclusion of primary products from NAFTA. Last night he was like a rabbit caught in a spotlight—and I felt sorry for him.

talk.start.para: —Charming.

—I am sure that if Senator Hill watched the television program, he may have thought, `Well, if we ever get government, how could this person be Deputy Prime Minister of this country?'. It is an old Liberal Party plot, in past coalition or future coalition governments, to grab the deputy prime ministership. If the Liberals ever win, they should ignore the Nationals and go for it. The last thing they would want is Mr Fischer in charge of this country with a travelling Prime Minister.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I asked a direct question on whether the Government had assessed the damage done to the grains industry and what it was going to do. The Minister has no answer to that and has turned the question around to attack the Leader of the National Party. I can understand the Minister's incompetence in not understanding the remotest thing about trade, but I do think he is going over the top in using that attack to disguise his incompetence. I ask you to call him to order.
—Order! I ask the Minister to wind up his answer.

—Mr President, I make no pretence to be an expert on trade. I was merely drawing the conclusion that someone like Mr Fischer, who proclaims himself to be a total professional in this area, was last night shown to be a total dope. What, in fact, he is doing in that sort of rhetorical comment is selling out rural Australia.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to ask the Minister to withdraw that last insinuation.
—Order! The use of the word `dope' is unparliamentary.
—Yes, I am sorry, I should have used the word `aspirant', Mr President.
—Order! I ask you to withdraw it.

—I withdraw. Coming to the point, I am trying to draw a distinction in Senator Boswell's mind—if that is possible—between inconsistent, loudmouthed, inflammatory statements that offer no solution, and trying to work through the international bodies to resolve these issues.
When one looks at some of the proposals that have come forward in GATT from the secretariat and others—far more sensible and far more vanguardist than the ones we have dealt with before—that is the obvious route on which Australia should concentrate.

para.tab: We can, of course, try to go down the path—and I am sure Senator Boswell does not agree, although his Party has on occasions—of the so-called retaliatory action. The difficulty is that when Senator Boswell and the rest of those opposite come forward with these retaliatory actions, they tend to hurt Australia more than they help. There is no point in saying that we will get rid of the Americans from the joint facilities when we benefit immensely by them.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise another point of order. It is clear that the Minister does not understand what he is talking about. Question Time is a valuable part of this Senate and it is being abused. If the Minister cannot answer the question intelligently, I ask you to sit him down and let someone else have a go. He has made a pathetic attempt to denigrate the National Party and he has not answered the question.
—Order! Senator Ray, can you conclude your answer.

—On the point that Senator Boswell has raised, I conclude on this note: maybe I am not an expert on trade, but I am trying to answer the question and Senator Boswell is not listening. I am not surprised, because he is not even trusted by his coalition colleagues to have an Opposition portfolio. Maybe the only thing they can deliver him relates to the big issue—not trade last weekend, but whether they want to go back to knighthoods and, no doubt, the Queensland experience of selling knighthoods. Maybe Senator Boswell will get that rather than a portfolio in a future government.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. On 22 June the Prime Minister launched the national waste minimisation and recycling strategy which he claimed would halve the amount of waste going to land fill and increase the amount of recycling in Australia. The strategy included a review of the tax system and its impact on recycling. A whole three days later, the Government announced that, irrespective of the fact that it was having this review, it was going to impose a 20 per cent tax on toilet and tissue paper, paper bags and exercise books made from recycled paper. I ask the Minister: why is the Government announcing a policy to, on the one hand, halve the waste we generate over the next eight years and, on the other hand, destroy the market for recycled toilet and facial tissue as well as threaten the jobs of hundreds of Australians who work in the paper recycling industry? Does the Government accept that the tax system is a legitimate instrument to influence recycling and to create markets for recycled goods?

—The tax system is a system which can help with policies of that kind. But a sales tax exemption is only one means of promoting environmentally sound practices. The Government has put in place a number of other initiatives.

para.tab: For example, it is fair to say that the pulp and paper industry's recycling performance in the last decade has been excellent by world standards. In absolute terms, the usage of waste paper for recycling has increased from 560,000 tonnes in 1980 to about one million tonnes in 1991—that is, it has doubled in use—but it has been without the benefit of any particular tax incentive. So these things can happen in various ways. For example, the recently announced national waste minimisation and recycling strategy, to which Senator Kernot referred, will provide a direct means of encouraging recycling.

The sales tax exemption on recycled toilet and facial tissue, exercise books and paper bags has contributed very little to the objective of saving native forests. Rather, it has led to distortions in the waste paper market, with high quality waste being directed to tax exempt and often single use products. I am not an expert on what has happened in respect of those high quality waste products, but that is my understanding of the position. So the two things that Senator Kernot juxtaposes in her question are not necessarily relevant to each other.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether the Government has made a decision that the jobs for employees of Kimberly-Clark, which uses virgin pulp, are more important than the jobs of employees of Australian owned companies—in this case Austissue, which uses recycled paper and recycled pulp. Is the Minister saying that the problem is one of imports, when his government cannot even tell us that it disaggregates imports? It does not even know how much recycled paper is being imported into the country.
—Order! This is a long supplementary question.

—Senator Kernot has rightly drawn attention to the fact that the sales tax exemption bears differently on different manufacturers and their operations—not just Kimberly-Clark but a number of other companies. I recognise that a number of companies have complained about the possibility of the abolition of the sales tax exemption.
—How do you decide?
—Senator Kernot interjects, `How do you decide?'. It is hard. Sometimes in government one has to make hard decisions. One cannot sit there and appear as a bleeding heart on every issue.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I refer to the confusion which the Government's Security in Retirement statement has created in respect of its proposed changes to the Defence Force pension arrangements. Firstly, will the Minister assure the Senate that Australian Defence Force personnel will still be able to commute part of their DFRDB pension to a lump sum before age 55? Secondly, in the light of this confusion and uncertainty, will the Minister extend the deadline by which personnel have to choose between the old and the new schemes beyond 30 September 1992?

—On the latter question, it is not within my ambit to be able to extend the scheme; that is a legislative provision which will remain extant. In relation to the second matter, there is still discussion occurring about the consequences of these things. I was informed this morning that those involved were fairly close to a resolution. I will not be able to make any assurances until we come to a final conclusion on those discussions. I understand that that is fairly close.

para.tab: Some of the changes will not necessarily affect those trying to make a decision between the two schemes. In either case there might be more compelling reasons. Those other provisions may in turn affect them, but not necessarily in terms of the cut-off point. On the second half of the senator's question, it is only possible to change the cut-off point by way of legislative change.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and it comes in two parts. First, has the Government yet made an assessment of the damage of the US trade decision to the Australian grain industry, and, secondly, why has the Government single-mindedly pursued a multilateral trade policy to the exclusion of bilateral and regional solutions to our trade dilemma?

—Let me take the second part of the question first. Successive trade Ministers from Michael Duffy through to John Kerin have taken the attitude that the first option will be a multi-issue approach. They are quite correct in taking that approach. However, we have made it clear that if the GATT round fails to progress, then everyone will be looking at other options. There is no question of that.
—You have been trying since 1986.

—Yes, we have been trying since 1986. I apologise to the National Party senator for the fact that his question has been hijacked. I will return to it in a moment. Yes, we did persist over a six-year period in these particular matters to try to get a result, because if we get the right result, it will be worth it. It will be worth it not only for our self-interest, but also for a lot of other countries' self-interest.

para.tab: With the GATT round resuming in September and again in November, we are again looking to try to make progress on these issues. As I understand it, the bureau has been doing an assessment of the cost to Australian wheat growers and it may be a more appropriate question to ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to see whether the final figuring is there. I heard some figures mentioned the other day in relation to this, but they had not been finalised and I do not feel that I am in a position to announce them now. I will pass that part of the senator's question on to the Minister for Primary Industries for his consideration. It may well be that that assessment will come out in the next few days.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I have no difficulty with the efficacy of supporting a multilateral trade solution through GATT, but my question is, why have we solely pursued a multilateral solution and not even attempted to pursue regional and bilateral trade solutions which may have given us critical access to markets at a time when we desperately need it?
—We have pursued issues such as CER, APEC and other matters.
—APEC is not a trade group.

—It is not yet, no. It has been going for a year or a year and a half, but through those forums we have been pursuing a variety of things. One of the difficulties in terms of credibility when one starts double dealing—that is, pursuing the sorts of bilateral blocs that the senator is talking about—is that one loses a lot of credibility in terms of getting a multilateral solution.

para.tab: Credibility is important in these matters. As we try to force countries into a position, in association with other colleague countries in a similar position to us, credibility is enormously important. It is not important to Senator Hill, who can have 10 different policies in five minutes. He is welcome to that. That is a luxury of opposition. It is not often a luxury that a government of a country has.

talk.start.para: —Will the Minister for Transport and Communications inform the Senate of current and future arrangements regarding flights from the United States to Australia via Japan?

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —This is an important question. If the concern that has been expressed to my office in the last 24 hours from both the tourist industry and two of our important primary industry exporters is anything to go by, it is important that the Government states clearly its position on this.

para.tab:
Air services between Australia and the United States are governed by the provisions of the 1946 air services transport agreement between our two countries. If the North Pacific route—that is, the right-angled route that the would-be deputy Prime Minister was inarticulating on on
Lateline
last night, the Japan route—is anything to go by, the 1946 agreement clearly allows the linking of the United States to Australia over Japan. As designated carriers, Northwest Airlines and United Airlines are entitled to operate an approved level of services to Australia via Japan.

In terms of the position that the leader of the National Party was taking last night, I have to say with the greatest respect that I hope those opposite are not actually serious about making that bloke deputy Prime Minister of Australia if they win the next election. That is a joke. How can they overlook Senator Bishop eight times for promotion and make Tim Fischer deputy Prime Minister of Australia? It is pathetic. It is not a trivial issue, because the leader of the second partner of the coalition has seriously suggested that this Government, and I as Minister, should tear up the 1946 air services agreement between Australia and the United States.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question asked what is the Government's policy. Senator Collins is not answering that; he is attacking this side of the chamber.
—Order! I ask Senator Collins to answer the question that was asked.

—That is precisely what I am doing. I can assure the Senate and I can assure the tourist industry, which would be so adversely affected by any such action, that we will not be doing it. Since 1989, United has had an approved level of two weekly jumbo services from the United States to Australia via Tokyo. United has not yet operated to Australia via Japan and only recently applied to take up its two services. The United Airlines' application is currently under consideration and a decision will be taken on that shortly. Northwest Airlines was given approval to operate three services per week from New York to Sydney via Osaka from October 1991.

para.tab: Northwest's services are conditional. They were given to Northwest on the condition that the services do not focus on Japan-Australia traffic—something which, I might add, is easily monitored—and that they do focus on passengers that are carried from the US to Australia via Japan. These decisions—and this seems to have been totally overlooked by the would-be deputy Prime Minister of Australia—taken by the Government had the effect of establishing a new route to Australia from the United States, with the attendant benefits not just for our tourism industry but also for two very important primary producers that are exporting from Australia; that is, the seafood and horticultural industries.

I was staggered by statements that were made over the weekend by the National Party which proposed ripping up the air services agreement—because that would be the effect of doing what Mr Fischer is suggesting we should do. I had hoped that these ridiculous statements might be contained to the National Party, but then Mr Jull, the shadow Minister for aviation, said:

answer.para: I would not like to do it but maybe you have got to revert to using future air rights negotiations as part of the overall deal.
This is the same Mr Jull who in July this year, just a month ago, in a major interview with a tourist trade magazine headlined, `The coalition would open skies further'—

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a further point of order. The question was: what is the Government's policy in relation to this matter? What has that got to do with Mr Jull? What has it got to do with Mr Fischer? I ask that you require Senator Collins to answer the question in the terms that it was asked rather than debate the matter.

talk.start.para:
—On 20 August Senator Bell asked me a question concerning the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and the Bureau of Mineral Resources. I seek leave to have the answer to his question incorporated in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

answer.para: As announced by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Resources on 13 August 1992, the resources allocated to petroleum and minerals resource assessment within the former Bureau of Mineral Resources (now the Australian Geological Survey Organisation) will be merged with the Bureau of Rural Resources to form a new professionally independent Bureau within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Also included will be the National Resource Information Centre which was previously operated jointly by the Bureau of Rural Resources and the Bureau of Mineral Resources.

The new Bureau, in conjunction with the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, offers the prospect of much-improved support for the Government's decision making on resources matters through better integration of biological, geoscientific and economic resource information and analysis.

Details of the transfer of the resource assessment functions have not yet been finalised. Preliminary indications, however, are that the transfer will involve less than 10 per cent of the former Bureau of Mineral Resources' resource base. The major direct expense will be the cost of the physical relocation of some 40 people, including fit-out of accommodation, which is likely to be in the order of $250 000. Other direct costs are expected to be minor as it is envisaged that computer databases and other data holdings will largely remain at their current location. Communication links are already in place which will meet the immediate operational needs of the transferred staff in connecting to and/or managing relevant computer databases. In addition there may be some indirect costs associated with accommodation rearrangements within the existing building and re-establishment of rented accommodation in order to take advantage of vacated space.

There will also be some costs for stationery and signage changes resulting strictly from the change of name, rather than the transfer of functions. These costs are not expected to be major as every effort will be made to avoid unnecessary expenditure. The change of name marks the change in the organisation's role and more closely reflects international and State practice for such bodies.

The transfer of staff will relieve to some extent the immediate accommodation difficulties being experienced by the Australian Geological Survey Organisation in its current building where the average floor-space per staff member is well below Australian Public Service guidelines. In their joint announcement, the Ministers stated that the Organisation will remain in its current accommodation until the review of administrative arrangements is completed and that in the interim, the Government will commit up to S5m to address accommodation issues, including immediate safety concerns in the current building.
