talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill on 20 August 1992, relating to the circumstances surrounding the removal of the Gillespie children.

speech.para: I am pleased that the Government has taken up what I believe has been its responsibility all along, and that is to properly investigate what appear to have been failures on behalf of our law enforcement authorities in that these children were taken out of the protection of the Australian jurisdiction apparently so easily. So far, the Australian Government has not been prepared to tell the Australian people how that occurred and what the shortcomings were or put down any form of remedial plan so that such an unfortunate occurrence might not occur again. At least the Minister for Justice has taken up the challenge of inquiry into the matters. That suggests perhaps that the Government does not know what went wrong, but I am pleased to hear that the Minister will now investigate the matters and report back.

para.tab: However, I am concerned with the terms of reference. One of the Minister's colleagues said to me that I would have the opportunity to peruse these terms of reference before they were formalised. Certainly they were not brought to my attention until Question Time was in progress, despite the fact that we had been ringing the Minister's office, I understand, for the last couple of days asking what was to happen in relation to this matter. But it does seem to me that there are deficiencies in the terms of reference that the Minister has put down in this matter.

The first deficiency is that the terms of reference do not seem to require the investigator to look at what changes in practice or coordination might be necessary to avoid a recurrence of such events. I would have thought that that was critically important and that he should make such recommendations. The second shortcoming in the terms of reference is that there is no instruction to investigate and advise what resources the Australian Federal Police or the Australian Customs Service in fact applied to this search for the Gillespie children. It has been alleged, of course, that the resources that were applied were insufficient. There has been some public debate about that but, I might say, on a shortage of facts. I think the Australian people have a right to know what form the investigation and search took and what level of re-

speech.para: sources were applied to that task. I believe that Mr Glenn should be instructed to investigate and to report publicly on those matters in his conclusions.

para.tab: I am pleased to the extent that the Minister has taken up what I think is his responsibility in this matter. I am disappointed, however, that these terms of reference seem to be unduly restrictive. I can only hope that his report will in fact cover matters that go beyond those which are strictly covered by the very limited terms of reference that the Minister has tabled in the chamber today.

debate.sub1.title: The Hon. Sir Thomas Charles Drake-Brockman DFC

talk.start.para: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 28 August 1992, of former Senator the Hon. Sir Thomas Charles Drake-Brockman, DFC, senator for the State of Western Australia from 1958 to 1978. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

speech.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on Friday 28 August 1992, of former Senator the Honourable Thomas Charles Drake-Brockman, Senator for the State of Western Australia from 1958 to 1978, Minister for Air from 1969 to 1972, Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister for Administrative Services in 1975 and Deputy President of the Senate from 1965 to 1969 and 1976 to 1978, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

speech.para: Thomas Charles Drake-Brockman was born on 15 May 1919 at Toodyay, Western Australia and was educated at Guildford Grammar School. He spent his early adult years in the Toodyay troop of the 10th Light Horse Regiment before enlisting in the RAAF in 1941 where he remained in active service until the end of World War II.

para.tab: His accomplishments while in the RAAF were many. He was posted overseas in 1941 as sergeant air-gunner and served in the Middle East, Malta and the United Kingdom. He took part in numerous bombing raids over the Middle East and Europe, was involved in mine-laying sorties in Tobruk Harbour and also managed to spend time in England as an instructor to an Australian training unit. In October 1943 he was commissioned as a pilot officer, attaining the rank of Flight Lieutenant, and in 1944 was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross.

Prior to entering Federal Parliament, Sir Thomas was a farmer and grazier. He was a member of the wool executive and then the general executive of the Farmers Union. He was President of the wool section of the Farmers Union of Western Australia and Vice President of the Australian Wool and Meat Producers Federation.

His long career in Federal Parliament began in 1958 and he was elected a further four times before his retirement in 1978. For six of those years he was Leader of the Country Party in this chamber and for a short period was Acting Leader of the Government. His ministerial appointments during that time included: Minister for Air from 1969 to 1972, serving under Prime Ministers John Gorton and Sir William McMahon, and Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister for Administrative Services in 1975.

His parliamentary appointments included: Temporary Chairman of Committees, two terms as Chairman of Committees, Acting President of the Senate and Deputy President of the Senate. Added to all of this was his membership over the years of several parliamentary committees and delegations.

Sir Thomas was a longstanding member of the Country Party, later the National Country Party. From 1963 he was the Federal representative on the State Executive of the Western Australian Branch of the Party and member of its Federal Executive Council. After his retirement he went on to the post of State President of the NCP and then Federal President, where he continued to fight for rural Australians.

He will be remembered as a friendly man with a great sense of humour. I certainly remember these qualities myself and his courtesy and respect for other people. He was a most genial person. In his role as Chairman of Committees he was noted, as he was in all his dealings, for his fairness and integrity, which rightly earned him the respect of his peers. He served this country tirelessly in many capacities throughout his life. In 1979 he was created a Knight Bachelor in recognition of his services to the Parliament and Australia.

When Tom Drake-Brockman retired from Parliament in 1978 former Senator Webster, who was then I think Leader of the then Country Party in this chamber, in his valedictory speech borrowed the words of a poet as part of his tribute. He said:
The heights by great men reached and kept
Were not attained by sudden flight,
But they, while their companions slept,
Were toiling upward in the night.

speech.para: It was an appropriate valediction at that time and remains so.

para.tab: On behalf of the Government, I extend our sincere sympathy to his wife, Mary, and his family in their bereavement.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Opposition senators, I join with the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) in expressing our regret at the death on 28 August, at the age of 73, of former Senator the Hon. Sir Thomas Charles Drake-Brockman, DFC.

para.tab: Sir Thomas was born in Western Australia in 1919 and educated at Guildford Grammar School. In 1938, after finishing school, he joined the 10th Light Horse Regiment. In 1941, he enlisted in the RAAF. His war service, as has been said by Senator Button, was most distinguished. It included postings in the Middle East, Malta and England. He rose to the rank of flight lieutenant and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross in July 1944, before being discharged from the RAAF in December 1945.

Mr President, he became a farmer after the war and was very active in both the Farmers Union of Western Australia—he was the President of its wool section from 1955 to 1958—and the Australian Wool and Meat Producers Federation, of which he was Vice President from 1956 to 1957.

As a staunch member of the Country Party, later the National Country Party, his prominence in rural affairs made him a natural choice when a Senate vacancy arose in 1958 on the death of Senator Seward. He went on to represent the people of Western Australia as a senator for 20 years.

His achievements as a parliamentarian also mark him as one of the most distinguished Australians of his time. His outstanding record of service included: Deputy President of the Senate from 1965 to 1969 and again from 1976 to 1978; Minister for Air from 1969 to 1972; Minister for Administrative Services and Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the Fraser caretaker government in November 1975; and Leader of the Country Party in the Senate from 1969 to 1975.

He had an enormous personal following in Western Australia, which assured his re-election in 1975 when the NCP no longer held seats in the House of Representatives. Former colleagues have described him as a very effective Minister and as a reliable and strong colleague.

In addition to his most significant achievement in the offices he held was his contribution to the coalition. I am reliably informed that he was a powerful force for unity at difficult times in the early 1970s. As a result of his efforts and the cooperative links he forged with the then Liberal leader in the Senate, Reg Withers, not only was the strength of the coalition greatly enhanced but also that of the Senate.

After his retirement from the Senate he was still very active in politics, including a stint as Federal President of the National Country Party from 1978 to 1981. He also played a major role in the Air Force Association and in his retirement played a key role in reviving the Australian and British Society where he served as president of the Western Australia branch from 1981.

His outstanding contributions to public life in Australia were officially recognised when he was knighted in 1979. On behalf of all coalition senators, I extend our most sincere condolences to Lady Drake-Brockman and to the family of the former senator.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —Mr President, on behalf of the National Party, I would like to extend the Party's sympathy to the family of the Hon. Sir Thomas Charles Drake-Brockman, DFC who passed away on 28 August in Perth at the age of 73.

para.tab: Sir Thomas led a life of great distinction. He was a man of great courage. He gave many years of service to public life, to rural industry and to my own Party, the National Party. Sir Thomas distinguished himself during the Second World War, seeing action in 63 bombing raids throughout Europe and the Middle East. As he was to do in later life, he served with distinction, being awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and rising to the rank of flight lieutenant.

In all the dangerous situations he faced during the Second World War, it is said that he never game a damn about the amount of flak around him. This was indicative of his attitude, whether it was on the football field where he was a fine Aussie rules footballer, in the air or in politics. He always played the game hard.

After returning to Australia and settling on the land, Sir Thomas became a prominent figure in the wool industry where he made a tremendous contribution to primary industry. He was the Vice-President of the Australian Wool and Meat Producers' Federation in 1956. In 1957 he became a wool executive member for seven years and was President of the wool section of the Farmers' Union of WA from 1955 to 1958.

After being chosen at the age of 39 as a senator by the Western Australian Government on the death of Senator Seward he went on to become the longest serving Western Australian senator, retiring in 1975 after 20 years service. His contribution to the National Party was immense. He had a distinguished record in the Country Party, as it was then called. He was leader of the National Party in the Senate for seven years from 1969 to 1975. After retirement from the Senate he was Federal President of the Party from 1978 to 1981. He held office in the Fraser caretaker Government and was Minister for Air from 1969 to 1972.

The National Party has lost one of its great members in the passing of Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman. Sir Thomas was a gregarious person with the ability to just gather people around him. I am told by members of parliament who served with him that he was great company, full of anecdotes, yarns and wartime stories, and that he had a great belief in serving his fellow man, never seeking any thanks, but approaching it all with great cheer.

In his maiden speech in this place he hit the ground running. He did not lose his first opportunity to put a very strong case for the wool industry in the desperate and disorganised state it was in then. The proposals he put forward—this speaks for the wool industry—were later to come about. But his emphasis was on the overall good of the country being based on a strong and stable wool industry and, of course, that is still the case.

Sir Thomas came from a distinguished, well-known family in Western Australia. He followed the family tradition by serving his nation in both war and peace and with a great sense of distinction and much achievement. He played the game hard but had many friends on all sides of politics. I am told by my colleagues that he was a man such that all were better off with Tom having passed their way.

It is an honour to join with the Government and the Liberal Party in this condolence motion for Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman who served his country with such devotion and distinction. I extend the sympathy of the National Party to his wife Mary and children Pauline, Barbara, David, Maxine and Joselynn and their families.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I join the Government, the Liberal Party and the National Party in this condolence motion for Sir Thomas Charles Drake-Brockman who was born, as others have said, in Toodyay in Western Australia in 1919, an area that I know reasonably well, although I never knew Sir Thomas. It is an area in the near wheat belt of Western Australia. As has been said, after the Second World War he went back to farming at Yerecoin near New Norcia, an area that is not far away from where he was born.

para.tab:
As has been mentioned, Sir Thomas was educated at Guildford Grammar School and joined the RAAF during World War II. As Senator Boswell has just pointed out and as shown in a little piece from the
West Australian
, he had a very distinguished career in the RAAF. The
West Australian
points out that he served with distinction as a pilot, joining the RAAF in 1941. He went on to take part in 63 bombing raids throughout Europe and the Middle East, including missions over Tobruk and during the battle of El Alamein. He rose to the rank of flight lieutenant and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross before being discharged from the RAAF in December 1945. He was clearly a man of great courage who was prepared to put his life on the line for his country. I was also interested to read that he later served as Minister for Air from 1969 to 1972. I reflect on how many Ministers today have actually had practical experience in the areas in which they later serve as Ministers.

As Senator Boswell has said, Sir Thomas also took a great interest in farming matters at the political level. He was President of the Wool Section and also the Vice President of the Australian Wool and Meat Producers' Federation immediately before he was elected into the Senate where he filled a casual vacancy in 1958. As others have pointed out, he went on to serve in the Senate for 20 years. At that time he was the longest serving senator. He represented the Country National Party, as it was in those days. In that capacity he also rose to the rank of Deputy President of this chamber between 1976 and 1978.

I was also interested to read that Sir Thomas was a great conciliator, particularly in the early 1970s. It is said in his biographical details that he was very effective in holding the National Country Party, as it was then, and the Liberal Party together in the Senate while in the House of Representatives evidently that happy situation did not obtain. Clearly, he was, as others have said, a man very able to bring people together and get them to work together. Immediately after he left the Senate he was knighted. Clearly, he went on to take a great interest in politics and continued to serve the country very well until his death. The Democrats join with the Government and the other parties in extending our condolences to his wife Mary and his children, Pauline, Barbara, David, Maxine and Joselynn.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support this motion of condolence on the death of Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman, a senator for a period of 20 years and a Minister and Chairman of Committees for quite a number of years in this chamber. I met Tom Drake-Brockman, although very briefly, in the 1970 Senate election campaign when we were political rivals in Western Australia. As is well-known, for 30 years or more the Liberal Party and the then National Country Party, now the National Party, had separate Senate tickets. The 1970 Senate election was no exception. At that election Tom Drake-Brockman was a Minister as well as a well-known senator. Our paths crossed very briefly during that election. As one is want to do in election campaigns, we had little personal contact as political rivals. However, shortly after that when I came into the Senate, Tom Drake-Brockman was the leader of the National Country Party in this chamber. Virtually, in effect, he was Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. It was from that time forward that I really got to know him.

para.tab: I wish to speak briefly of the eighteen months that I observed Sir Thomas as a Minister, which was from about 1971 to 1972, the second half of his period as a Minister in the chamber. He was a most effective Minister. I speak mostly of his performance in this chamber where, as Minister, he represented a number of portfolios other than his own, all of which he handled with great aplomb and political finesse. For several months he was the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. He performed that role—although it was thrust upon him somewhat unexpectedly, for that period of time at least—most effectively and I was most impressed by him. As the years passed to 1978 we became very much better known to each other and we became very close political friends.

Sir Thomas was a most solid performer in this chamber, not only in his role as a Minister but also, as I have mentioned, as a very effective Chairman of Committees. He was a great colleague. It was a great shame that his career as a Minister was not resumed after the 1975 election. Because of the exigencies of the political fortunes of his party, at that election he was elected only tenth—at that time each State had 10 senators. His election as a senator was not certain for some weeks and by that time the Fraser Government had been formed. Unfortunately, he was not able to be included in it. I always thought this was a shame because he certainly deserved to become a Minister again in 1975, even though he would have held that position only until his retirement in 1978. Nevertheless, Tom Drake-Brockman resumed his position as Chairman of Committees for the remainder of his term in the Senate.

I particularly remember him in terms of the heady political days of 1974 and 1975. We were colleagues in the shadow ministry. He was then Leader of the National Country Party and a shadow Minister. I can remember very well the events of 11 November 1975. Funnily enough, he always comes to my mind when I recall this event because he was the first person who told me of the dismissal. I came into the chamber just before 2 p.m. The bells were ringing prior to the Senate resuming for the afternoon. I do not think we had Question Time on that day or at that time. Tom Drake-Brockman and I sat next to each other. As soon as I sat down he said, `Do you know that Gough has been dismissed?', or words to that effect. It was just as well that I had sat down—it was such a surprise that I would have needed to. Indeed, he failed to convince me that what he said had happened was in fact true. Only a few minutes later the Appropriation Bills were called on. Reg Withers got up and said that the Opposition would agree that the Bills we had been fighting bitterly over for some weeks be passed. That is my most vivid memory of my association with Tom Drake-Brockman.

As Senator Hill has already said, a very strong partnership was formed between Tom Drake-Brockman, his colleagues and ourselves, even though there was not a formal coalition in the Senate. This situation was repaired and we had a very solid coalition in 1974 and 1975.
Tom Drake-Brockman was a most valuable member of the team. He was a very loyal and genial colleague. We continued to work very closely together until his retirement in 1978. I very much regret his passing and extend my deepest sympathy to his widow and his family.

talk.start.para: —I also offer my condolences in respect of the passing of Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman. Probably I do so from a different perspective to other people in this place. As has already been mentioned, Sir Thomas and his family—or Tom Drake-Brockman, as we knew him—farmed at Yericorn about 15 miles down the road from where my father's property was. I extend my condolences to Lady Mary, Pauline, Barbara, David, Maxine and Joselynn, and their families.

para.tab: I would like to make a few brief observations about what I remember of that time. It has already been noted that Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman was an old Guildfordian. His son and I also attended Guildford Grammar School. Of course, I got to know Sir Thomas through my association with Guildford Grammar School.

My first memory of Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman was the involvement that he had with my father in the wool industry in Western Australia. Although I was not very old at that time—I was probably 14 or 15—I used to attend industry meetings with my father. Names that come to mind are Bill Ball from Katanning and Eric Hitchin from, I believe, Tambellup. They played an enormous role at that time in changes that were made to the Australian Wool Board. I can remember attending a meeting at Miling about 1957, the year after I left school. At that meeting Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman outlined suggested changes to the wool industry. This was before the Australian Wool Commission was established.

I think it is rather tragic that the principles that were outlined at that time by Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman and others were forgotten some time down the track. The role of the Wool Commission, which became the Wool Corporation, changed. The Commission operated very well for a number of years. It then became the Wool Corporation. A number of things happened. As a result, the Corporation changed its role and tried to become a price setting authority. I remember those events well. Certainly, the Western Australian wool producers owe a great debt of gratitude to Tom Drake-Brockman for the role that he then played.

I must also comment on the role that Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman played in respect of the Australian Wool and Meat Producers Federation. When I first became a member of the executive of what was known as the Farmers Union, which later became the Farmers Federation, I can remember sitting down with Sir Don Eckersley and talking with Tom Drake-Brockman, who was Vice President of the AWMPF. The AWMPF was a forerunner of the National Farmers Federation—it was an organisation that amalgamated with the Australian Woolgrowers and Graziers Council. Sir Thomas was involved at that time—this was carried on later by Sir Don Eckersley and others—in steering the industry towards what is now known as the National Farmers Federation.

I particularly wanted to make those points in this debate because not only did Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman have a distinguished career in politics but also he had a very distinguished career in the formulation of agricultural politics in Western Australia. Certainly, the farmers of Western Australia owe him a debt of gratitude for the contribution he made at that time.

I also remember Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman well for another reason. One of his virtues was that he was a great communicator. When he went into politics he made it his business to inform as often as possible members of the Farmers Union what was going on. He was also a great listener. I certainly learnt a lot from him. I learnt that while we have a role in life to communicate things, we also have a role to listen to what people have to say, to absorb that message and to pass it on in appropriate forums.

Those are the things that I remember very succinctly about Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman. I am sure that if my father were still with us he would certainly endorse the comments that I have made about his friend Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman—or Tom as he knew him. At that time my father was very heavily involved in local government. My uncle, Bert Crane, who served in the Western Australian Parliament for a long period, spent time with Tom Drake-Brockman and others discussing the general development of the Moora-Wongan Hills-New Norcia area. These are points that I remember well—I think they are worth putting on the record.

I close emphasising the role that Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman played in a variety of areas in the district in which I spent the first 25 years of my life. Once again, I express my condolences to Lady Mary and the family.

speech.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: —Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman was a great Australian not because of the role he played or the positions he held but because he lived the life of a great Australian. Everybody who knew him has said that he was a man of courage, a man of commitment and, most importantly, a man of charm and courtesy—and they are qualities to be admired in any Australian.

para.tab: He was a great member of the Country Party, the National Country Party and the National Party. All of us in the National Party will miss him and the contribution that he had to make not only to our Party but to the nation as a whole. He was a man who acted out of belief and commitment, and a man who really did what he thought was in the best interests of the country.

As has been said today, he was also a war veteran. What greater unit or force to have been involved with than the Tenth Light Horse Regiment, a unit which has a position of pride and fame in Australian history; and, of course, the RAAF, in which he served in the Mediterranean, in Malta and El Alamein, in 63 bombing raids in that very fierce area of conflict. Not many pilots actually finished that many bombing raids, so perhaps somebody up above wanted Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman to go on to play the role that he did in this Parliament, in his Party and in his nation.

He was a man who never gave up; a man who always fought; and, quite appropriately, a man who was rewarded, albeit before the end of his career, with the position of Minister for Air. Apparently, it was not a position that he particularly wanted. He wanted to be Minister for Repatriation and when told he was to be Minister for Air, he was reported to have said, `Oh no, VIP aircraft and F111s'. He was famous for refusing the future Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Malcolm Fraser, the use of a VIP aircraft on one occasion. The fact that he fulfilled that role so well speaks tomes for his ability and his capacity to make things run when others believed that they could be not be achieved.
Senator Button, in his very eloquent and moving address, quoted some verse about Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman; I quote another piece from Byron which says:

speech.para: Each lucid interval of thought
Recalls the woes of Nature's charter;
And he that acts as wise men ought,
But lives, as saints have died, a martyr.

After 1975 Sir Thomas Drake-Brockman really did miss out on a ministry, but he carried on his commitment to this place and this institution by continuing as Deputy President. After he left, he continued his commitment to the Party and was a great Federal President.

para.tab: The National Party is very much like a family, and I take this opportunity to extend to his wife Mary, his children and his grandchildren our heartfelt sympathy.

talk.start.para: —I think it was on 10 June 1978 that the Senate farewelled Senator Tom Drake-Brockman. As a matter of fact, we also farewelled on that day Senator Kerry Sibraa. He made a return to this place, and I trust and pray that Senator Drake-Brockman has gone to a better place than making a return to this place. That, of course, is no reflection on the President; I think he has graced this place as well. On that occasion we also farewelled some others, including Reg Wright, Don Devitt and Sir Magnus Cormack.
—Not Reg.

—Yes, we did farewell Reg Wright. You were here, Mr Deputy President, and by your nod I see that I am correct. We farewelled a number of other senators—I think Reg Bishop was amongst them—who had served this place long and contributed much to this chamber's effectiveness. I think all of them did so. Tom Drake-Brockman was for a while, albeit a fairly short while of about a year, Deputy President of this chamber and also Chairman of Committees. My recollection is that he held an office in the old Parliament House overlooking the lake—I think one of the best offices in the place—and one used to repair there from time to time.

para.tab: Tom Drake-Brockman was an effective person in the chamber itself but was probably far more effective in the organisational situation, as, of course, befitted members of the National Country Party at the time. They were always far more effective behind closed doors than they appeared to be within the public debate. Of course, they very often got their way—so much so, that very often the tail was accused of wagging the dog. Tom Drake-Brockman left this place and went into that area of organisation again, I think as President of the National Country Party in Western Australia.
I associate myself very sincerely with this condolence motion and take the opportunity of expressing publicly my sympathy for his widow, his children—who are grown up now—and his grandchildren.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

speech.speaker: Kernot Sen C.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Leave is granted. The honourable senator may proceed.

—Senator Panizza is right; it is not something that I do lightly. Politics is sometimes a nasty business, as everybody here knows, and I do not object to receiving constructive criticism as part and parcel of that. But I take strong issue with recent comments of Senators Short and Lewis in the adjournment debate of 20 August 1992. They were absolutely wrong, as I will go on to demonstrate.
—But they were right.

—Senator Patterson had better listen carefully. The subject matter of the Opposition senators' statements is the effect of the indirect tax system on the business operations of the farm machinery sector. As honourable senators will be aware, the Government has introduced Bills which propose to totally restructure the wholesale sales tax.

para.tab:
A question arose as to whether the existing concessionary system which allows farm machinery dealers to buy their goods and parts sales tax free would be able to continue under the new arrangements. My office received hundreds of standard form letters on this issue. I seek leave to have one of them incorporated in
Hansard
.
Leave granted.

The letter read as follows
—

speech.para: Senator Cheryl Kernot
Parliament House
Canberra
Re: Sales Tax Legislation
Dear Senator Kernot,

A number of submissions have been made to the Senate Select Committee for Sales Tax Legislation expressing the concerns of the farm machinery industry and in particular those of we, the dealers, who will be expected to bear the cost of the proposed changes.

Our major concern is that goods purchased by dealers for subsequent retail sale for use in agriculture (a sales tax exempt industry) will attract 20% sales tax until refunded by the Tax Office following the retail sale which may occur months later.

Although we are advised that Section 84 of the proposed new legislation allowed the Tax Commissioner discretionary power to treat stock purchases as tax exempt in a similar manner as applies today, we are opposed to reliance upon this discretion as it is dependant upon the view of an individual rather than a defined set of guidelines.

We therefore strongly request that the legislation is amended to ensure that conditions pertaining to sales tax in an exempt industry remain as they are today where there is no unnecessary financial burden on the middleman, in this case the dealer.
Clearly if this legislation goes through unamended there is a distinct possibility that some dealers will be unable to comply with the financial impost and will decide to cease operations.
Your consideration and implementation of the above would be appreciated.
Yours faithfully,

(Sgd)
Dealership John Dwyer Group

Dealer Principal
Town Mackay State Queensland

talk.start.para:
—I suspect that the campaign was organised by the Opposition or someone associated with it. This was orally confirmed to one of my staff members who was explaining the situation to a worried farm machinery dealer. Notwithstanding the claim of orchestration, the matter raised was a serious one. I, and also Opposition members of the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation, raised the matter with the Taxation Office and got a formal reply which basically said that the existing arrangements, which we all supported, will remain under the new system. I then wrote a standard letter of response to the inquiries and distributed it to some of the people who had contacted my office. I seek leave to have that incorporated in
Hansard
as well as I do not resile from one word of it.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The letter read as follows
—

speech.para: SENATOR CHERYL KERNOT
Australian Democrat Senator for Queensland
TREASURY, FINANCE, ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS, ELECTORAL MATTERS
18 August 1992
Dear Proprietor
RE your recent fax on farm machinery

The Australian Democrats support the current system of allowing retailers to purchase stock free of sales tax, where the eventual sale will be exempt from tax. I raised this matter with the Taxation Office officials at a public hearing of the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax recently and they informed the Committee that the current situation will not change.
I enclose a copy of the answer by the Taxation Office which seems to indicate that you have been misinformed about the impact of this legislation.

I think you should be aware that the GST will impose an automatic tax penalty on farm machinery dealers. That is, your business will be detrimentally affected by the GST in exactly the manner that you feared would happen under the new whole sales tax regime
According to the Fightback! documents, GST will be payable on all your stock purchases, including all transitional stocks held at the time of the introduction of the GST.
Yours sincerely,
Cheryl Kernot
Australian Democrat Senator for Queensland
Australian Democrat Treasury Spokesperson

talk.start.para: —According to the Opposition, this is where I committed my cardinal sin for which Senator Lewis called me a cheat and a liar—
—Hear, hear!
—Mr President, I ask that that comment be withdrawn, by its implication.
—I withdraw `hear, hear'.

—I thank Senator Baume; we know what he means by it. In the letter I had the temerity to point out to the farm machinery dealers that a problem of exactly the same nature as the one they had identified, which the new legislation was not seeking to implement, would materialise if the Opposition's GST were enacted. The source of my contention is the Fightback package. The key problem which the farm machinery dealers identified in their letter to me was as follows:

speech.para: Our major concern is that goods purchased by dealers for subsequent retail sale for use in agriculture—
currently an exempt industry—
will attract 20% sales tax—
that is not the problem; the problem is:
until refunded by the Tax Office following the retail sale which may occur months later.

In their representations, the farm machinery dealers did not worry about the imposition of the sales tax per se but about the costs imposed on the dealers by having to pay tax which will be refunded by the Tax Office in due course. Indeed, the representations referred to an `unnecessary financial burden on the middle man, in this case the dealer'. I quote further:
. . . a distinct possibility that—

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Of course, we welcome the personal explanation by Senator Kernot but it does seem to me that she is debating the issue and straying far beyond a personal explanation. I seek your ruling on it.

—Mr President, if I could speak on the point of order, the details of my letter were quoted in the adjournment debate. I think it is necessary to go through the representations that were made to me and to answer why I concluded my letter in the way that I did in those last two paragraphs.
—I am worried about this developing into a debate. It is a personal explanation. I will listen carefully in view of your explanation.
—We will have one if you want one, just to prove your ignorance.

—I do not think Senator Knowles understands this. The point is that the greatest imposition of the 15 per cent GST is on the transitional stock of the dealers—that is the point the dealers were making. That is, $150,000 will have to be borrowed for every $1m of stock. The dealers will have to pay interest. This is the point of misrepresentation. Those opposite omitted the fact that the dealers will have to pay interest on those funds even though they will eventually get the money back. That is the problem—the financial impost.

para.tab: In conclusion, the line being parroted is, `Don't worry, these taxes are being rebated'. That is true, but the point is that they are not being rebated immediately and that is the dealers' problem. For many businesses the GST period will be six months, although it may be as little as one month for large firms. The Opposition has not listened to the real substance of the complaint, which is not a matter of whether it is rebatable but of the financial imposition of the interim period when the dealers have to carry this stock. That is the nature of the complaint, not what Opposition senators claim was my representation of it. Whether they can reclaim the ground is up to them, but I think their attack was cowardly and offensive.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion to take note of Senator Kernot's personal explanation and to make a brief comment in response to it.
—Is leave granted?

—Mr President, in order to forestall any lengthy debate, which you indicated this might develop into, the Government would be willing to grant leave to Senator Short alone for an equal period of time.

para.tab:
Opposition senators
—No.

talk.start.para: —Then I am going to refuse leave for a full debate.
—Is leave granted?

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —With respect, I am not prepared to accept leave on the basis that Senator Tate has given it. Senator Kernot has raised a point which shows that she fundamentally misunderstands the whole of one of the central elements of the coalition's Fightback proposal. There are many senators on this side who will want to make a point in relation to that. The personal explanation relates not only to comments I made in the Senate but also to comments made by Senator Lewis, and I am sure he would like the right to respond as well.
—Order! Senator Short sought leave to move a motion to take note of Senator Kernot's statement. Is leave granted?
—Yes.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the personal explanation.

speech.para: I raised this matter, to which Senator Kernot has now responded by way of personal explanation, during the adjournment debate on Thursday, 20 August 1992. It came up as a result of a letter which Senator Kernot had sent, as I understand it, to most farm machinery dealers, certainly over a very wide area if not the whole of Australia. I was drawn to make a comment on this matter for two reasons. As I said in the Senate on that evening, I have two problems with the letter, one more important than the other.

para.tab: The less important problem was the implication that I felt could be read into the letter that it was the Australian Democrats alone who had raised the concern that farm machinery dealers had with the Government's proposals to supposedly `simplify' its sales tax regime. In fact, it was a matter that had been of great concern and had been raised by coalition senators as well.

talk.start.para: —I acknowledge that.
—That was the less important of the points I raised. Senator Kernot has now acknowledged that and I thank her for that.

para.tab: The second, and much more important, issue that I raised—as I said, the second part of Senator Kernot's letter concerns me a great deal more—is that part of the letter which says:

speech.para: I think you should be aware that the GST will impose an automatic tax penalty on farm machinery dealers. That is, your business will be detrimentally affected by the GST in exactly the manner that you feared would happen under the new wholesale sales tax regime.
She went on to say:

para.tab: According to the Fightback! documents, GST will be payable on all your stock purchases, including all transitional stocks held at the time of the introduction of the GST.

speech.para: With great respect to Senator Kernot's so-called understanding of tax matters, what she says in that letter reveals that she does not have a clue about how the GST works. That is appalling for the key spokesperson of a party which says with great arrogance that, on a coalition government coming to office, it will block the proposals to introduce the GST. The arrogance of that to the Australian community is absolutely mind-blowing. That arrogance, based on a complete misunderstanding and ignorance of how the GST works, compounds the problem in an almost unbelievable way.

para.tab: There are two reasons why that statement is fundamentally wrong. Firstly, there is an implication in the statement that GST would be paid on that machinery. That is not so. Farm machinery is a business input and, therefore, is fully tax rebatable. The clear implication in the first of those two paragraphs that I quoted is that GST will be paid on that machinery. Senator Kernot must surely know that that is not true. If she does not know it, her level of ignorance is appalling. If she does know it, she wilfully set out to mislead the farm machinery dealers and farmers of Australia.

Senator Kernot should listen because she is talking at the moment to someone who knows even less about the GST than she does. I suggest that she concentrate on this. She has misled the Parliament and the farm machinery dealers and farmers of Australia. This is something that she ought to listen to. The second paragraph, to which I take great exception because it is wrong, says:
According to the Fightback! documents, GST will be payable on all your stock purchases, including all transitional stocks held at the time of the introduction of the GST.

speech.para:
Where that is wrong is that
Fightback!
specifically says that sales tax that has been paid on stock will be repaid; therefore, at the time of the introduction of the GST. Far from it being the problem that Senator Kernot talks about, the GST will provide a very significant cash flow bonus to dealers. They will get back the money that they have paid on the wholesale sales tax regardless of whether or not that machinery gets sold within a reporting period. In other words, those for whom the machinery sits as stock for a lengthy period will be massively better off for cash flow than they are now. So Senator Kernot is absolutely wrong in what she says as far as the implications of the GST are concerned.

talk.start.para: —`When' is the point they're making.

—I cannot make it any simpler than that. How Senator Kernot can imply that, because of the introduction of the GST, farm machinery dealers will be worse off in relation to the wholesale sales tax regime—which is what she says in that paragraph—is beyond me, because it is simply incomprehensible.

para.tab: I note Senator Kernot's personal explanation. All I can say is that she has compounded the misrepresentation, wilful or otherwise, of which she was guilty and of which I accused her of being guilty on 20 August. I suggest that she goes and has another try at understanding what it is all about.

speech.speaker: Panizza Sen J.H.

talk.start.para: —I want to enter into this debate. Firstly, I certainly plead guilty to providing fax numbers to the machinery dealers—
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Does Senator Panizza need the leave of the Senate to speak?

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)
—No. I have it on authority that—

talk.start.para: —That is all right. I want to make that quite clear, because you heard what Senator Tate said. He gave leave on the basis of there being just one speaker.

para.tab:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —That is all right. If those opposite want anarchy, they will get it.

—I am glad that Senator Schacht is interested in the conduct of the Senate; he does not seem to be at Question Time. I plead guilty to providing fax numbers to the machinery dealers of Western Australia so that they could contact Senator Kernot to inform her of their plight of being hit with sales tax pending the proposed sales tax legislation.

para.tab: No farm machinery dealer complained to me that GST would be applied to their purchases. No-one complained in the way that Senator Kernot suggested. No-one in Western Australia complained to me that farm machinery dealers would be hit with the GST and that they would have to carry it until the day their machinery was sold. It is a matter of explanation; no-one complained to me. The letter that Senator Kernot sent around was mischief-making.

I would have thought that Senator Kernot, after the fiasco over Comcar last year—and I will return to that issue another day—would have been more careful about what she did. She sent around a letter explaining what happened. It reads:

speech.para: I think you should be aware that the GST will impose an automatic tax penalty on farm machinery dealers. That is, your business will be detrimentally affected by the GST in exactly the manner that you feared. . .

Nowhere in this letter does she say that the GST will be refunded. Why did she not explain that further on? She did not do it; she never said it. Senator Short pointed out, as I will, that Senator Kernot failed to understand that where GST is paid—

para.tab:
Senator Kemp interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Hang on a minute. The GST is charged against machinery dealers when they take delivery from the wholesaler, but they are able to make an immediate request to the Australian Taxation Office for its refund. They do not have to wait one, two, three or six months, as Senator Kernot suggested when she misled the Parliament. They do not have to wait at all; they can make an immediate request for a refund. Under the GST proposal, if the Taxation Office does not pay them within 15 days, it has to pay interest on top of the refund.

para.tab: Let us get to Senator Kernot's lack of knowledge of paying interest while you wait. Obviously, Senator Kernot knows nothing about machinery dealers. As I have said before in this chamber, she has probably never ever been in business or paid out one day's wages to anyone. You fail to understand that they have 30 days credit before they pay for the machine.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)
—Order! Senator Panizza, if you were to address your remarks through the Chair, we may not have so many interjections.

talk.start.para: —I apologise, Madam Acting Deputy President. That machinery dealer has 30 days credit before they have to pay for that machine, and in some cases they have a lot longer to pay. During that 30 days the machinery dealer can have his GST refunded and after 15 days he will get interest. It is as simple as that. Can Senator Kernot tell me how on earth the machinery dealer will be disadvantaged or—as she has misled the Senate—have to pay any interest? It will be refunded in 15 days and, if not, interest will be paid on it and the dealer will pay for his machine at the end of the 30 days. I wish Senator Kernot would stick to speaking on subjects she knows about without misleading the machinery dealers of Western Australia as she has done in that letter; and, what is more, she ought to apologise.

—I was in the chamber when I had to experience the unfortunate events that Senator Short was referring to during the adjournment debate on that particular Thursday. Senator Kernot had been in the chamber and had participated in the adjournment debate. I was amazed to hear Senator Short say that he did not have an opportunity to raise the matter earlier in the day with Senator Kernot as she had been in this chamber taking part in the adjournment debate. Senator Short took it upon himself to wait until the very end of that adjournment debate and then make a great personal attack on Senator Kernot.
—He waited until he got the call. Don't you tell lies.

—Senator Kernot was in here taking part in the adjournment debate. Is that a lie? I have not told an untruth. Senator Short took the opportunity to wait until Senator Kernot had left and then claim that he had not had any chance to raise this matter with her during the day. Taking advantage of that strategic move, Senator Short then proceeded to outline what he thought was Senator Kernot's misunderstanding of their policy.
—If she wants to go home while the Parliament is sitting, she has to take the consequences.

—She was not at home. She was in fact unable to take any further part in the debate in which she had already spoken. Senator Baume should not misrepresent the position. He does not know where she was; I do. Having taken that strategic position, Senator Short was then able to further compound his unfair treatment of Senator Kernot by suggesting that her letter did not—
—Why didn't she make a personal explanation if she was here? You've got it wrong again.

—She could not take part in the debate; she had already spoken. The strategic advantage taken by Senator Short was then further compounded by him suggesting that certain parts of Senator Kernot's letter did not understand the Opposition's precious GST regime.

para.tab: In fact, what had happened was that a number of machinery dealers had written to Senator Kernot. I received a number of letters myself. The prime concern of these machinery dealers was that the Government's proposed changes to the sales tax legislation would disadvantage them. In fact, those machinery dealers had not been led to believe that that would occur. They had not been led to believe that by the Government and they certainly had not been led to believe that by the Democrats. They were led to believe that there was a problem with the legislation by somebody else. I will not presume to guess who that somebody else might have been.

The fact is that they got it wrong, because the questions which were addressed to the personnel from the Australian Taxation Office during the Senate inquiry into the matter showed that there was a misunderstanding as to the effect of this particular legislation. It was feared that machinery agents would have to find an extra 20 per cent on top of their purchase price from their wholesalers and carry that on the floor.

In fact, their fears were unfounded and Senator Kernot merely wrote to these people to explain to them that these fears had been removed by the answers given to the Senate inquiry. I see no great crime in that. The only crime of which Senator Kernot stands accused today is the crime of omission: she failed to explain the full details of the GST proposals, the precious Fightback package, that we have not been allowed to raise, mention or even discuss in this chamber.

That failure to spell it out in 47 pages of foolscap mumbo jumbo is a failure of which I am rather proud. I am rather proud that Senator Kernot did not waste any space doing that, because we have just heard from Senator Panizza the procedures that a farm machinery dealer would have to go through to get the rebate. We have had explained to us that the tax is paid, an application is made and then it has to be refunded. Senator Kernot's letter did not say anything other than that the tax would have to be paid and there would be a period of transition. There was no mention of how long that had to be, whether it had to be a bureaucratic form filling exercise or whatever. However, those very same fears which had applied to the potential of the Government's proposed legislation still apply in full force to what is proposed under the precious GST garbage.

speech.speaker: Lewis Sen A.W.R

talk.start.para: —I was present during the adjournment debate on this particular evening and Senator Short showed me a copy of the letter which Senator Kernot had apparently written to all of the farm machinery salesmen in Australia. He drew my attention to the third paragraph, which says:

speech.para: I think you should be aware that the GST will impose an automatic tax penalty on farm machinery dealers. That is, your business will be detrimentally affected by the GST in exactly the manner that you feared would happen under the new wholesale sales tax regime.

When I read that I said to Senator Short, `It is clear that Senator Kernot does not understand. When you speak on this matter in the Senate, go easy on her because it is clear that she does not understand that this is fully tax rebatable and that this will be an enormous advantage to these people who currently pay wholesale sales tax and do not get their money back until they have sold the machinery'.

para.tab: Under this system they will have the tax rebated at the time when they lodge their next return. They will get back any tax they have paid on the date of their next return, whether they have sold the machinery or not.

talk.start.para: —You're wrong.
—That is right.
—You're wrong.
—The tax is rebated immediately they lodge their next return. This ought to be explained to this senator who claims to be the spokesperson for the Democrats.
—I am.

—She is the spokesperson for the Democrats. As I was saying this to Senator Short, Senator Kernot's colleague Senator Bell walked past. I took the opportunity to draw his attention to this and to ask whether someone would explain to Senator Kernot what it was all about. Senator Bell said to me, `She knows, Senator. She knows what it is all about. What she has done is leave out the part where you get your money back'. As Senator Bell said a few moments ago during this debate, `Her crime is one of omission, and I am proud that she omitted that'. Senator Kernot should not get cross with me about what I am saying because what her colleague said to me was that she was a liar. She has quite clearly and deliberately written to these people and cheated and lied to them about our goods and services tax by the crime of omission.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The word `liar' has been ruled on by the President of this chamber many times.
—He was quoting someone.

—I have just heard Senator Lewis use the word in relationship to another honourable senator in this place and it was used as if it were a fact. I believe in those circumstances he has offended against the rule laid down by the President. In those circumstances Senator Lewis ought to be required to withdraw.

—I withdraw. All I was pointing out was that it is her colleague who is making this case against her—not me. He made the case to me and he has made it again today. He has said that it is her crime of omission—they were the words he used—and he said, `I am proud that she omitted this explanation to these people'. Senator Kernot has written to hundreds, thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of people telling them something which is simply not true, and she has done it deliberately.

para.tab: I say to her that I certainly shall not apologise to her for the words I used in that event. As a matter of fact, I think Senator Kernot ought to apologise to all of those people for using Senate notepaper to write out this sort of a letter which contains this total falsehood.

talk.start.para: —I have a very brief comment to make in this debate on Senator Kernot's personal explanation. I came into this chamber and sat waiting to move a notice of motion and fell into listening to this debate. All I have to say to the senators opposite—to Senator Short, Senator Panizza and Senator Lewis—is that they have just proven the extraordinary political problem they have of trying to explain the GST.

para.tab: I listened to Senator Panizza's explanation and I think the GST is impossible to explain. It is convoluted, it is twisted and it is no wonder those opposite are all feeling very sensitive because they cannot explain the fact that they are putting a tax on people. They then tell us that there are going to be rebates; there are to be rebates on interest apparently. All I can say is: regardless of what Senator Kernot raised, I have just listened to the best explanation from the Opposition of the political difficulties they will have with the GST, and I look forward to the next election campaign.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —The GST is really not a hard proposition to grasp. I have just explained it to Senator Kernot and it took me about 30 seconds. If she misunderstands after my simple explanation, then I think there are none so blind as those who do not want to see.
—It is not what I said. It is what the dealers are saying.

—It is not what the dealers are saying because they are quite clear. It is what Senator Kernot is confusing them with. It is a very simple explanation. Let me just put it to the Senate as someone who sold to farm machinery dealers for 18 years before I got into this place. If a farm machinery dealer buys $1m worth of parts or tractors in 30 days, he pays $1m and $150,000 as GST. At the end of 15 days, he gets that $150,000 back because that will be enshrined in legislation. He has to get that back because that is what the legislation says.

para.tab: Let me just look at some of the up sides for this particular machinery dealer. In the past, he has not paid sales tax on farmers' parts, but that same dealer may have tools, he may have letterboxes, he may have paint in his store, and all of this attracts a sales tax. It is not complex. He may have a stock of $300,000. In a hardware store, that stock turns over about four times a year. So when he pays tax on an item, say, a tool box for $10, he is paying $1.50. Before the GST, he may have had to sit on that item for 12 months before he got his sales tax rebated. Now, he gets his sales tax rebated in 15 days.

It will be a boon for the retail industry. Average hardware stores probably have half a million dollars worth of merchandise, all of it attracting sales tax of about $75,000. talk.start.para: —I rise to make a couple of brief points. para.tab:
Just to draw to the attention of the chamber the sort of gross error that has been made by Senator Kernot, I have in my hand a document called, surprisingly,
Getting to Work

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order—

—Please sit down.

para.tab: Senator Schacht said the Opposition had some difficulties explaining the GST to the Australian people. Government members have some difficulties explaining to the Australian people why anyone should believe the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—the man who said there would be no recession, the man who said there would be no capital gains tax, the man who agreed that no child would live in poverty. They have real problems explaining the credibility of their Prime Minister.

talk.start.para: —I find the whole explanation that Senator Kernot has given to this most extraordinary letter absolutely amazing. To think that she is not even prepared to listen the debate now, that she will go out of here still not understanding the difference between what she has said and reality, is just incredible. I suppose that if one were to be generous one could understand why Senator Kernot would not comprehend what we are talking about in regard to taxation reform. She has had no business experience in any way, shape or form—

—I understand this from Senator Kernot herself. Quite some time ago she told me that she did not have any business experience. That probably also explains why in Senator Kernot's letter she is obviously selling wholes. Selling wholes, one might ask? Because she is talking about the new `whole sales tax'. That is how much she understands about sales tax. We are now talking about a whole sales tax—not a wholesale tax, but a whole sales tax. But never mind. I suppose that Senator Kernot would also not know the difference between a payments basis and an invoice basis for a reporting period in GST.
—Of course not.

—At least we have had one admission. Twice Senator Kernot has said that she does not know the difference between the payments basis and the invoice basis. If she did understand those things, she would understand that the machinery dealer, or any other dealer for that matter, will not be adversely affected by the goods and services tax; they will, in fact, be in front with the goods and services tax.
—The point is that they are now liable when they were not before. That is the only point they're making.

—Goodness gracious me! That is the point that Senator Kernot is repeating as truth. It is nothing short of flabbergasting to think that Senator Kernot can sit in this chamber and still make the comments that she made earlier. Senator Short tried to explain it to her. Senator Panizza, Senator Kemp, Senator Lewis and Senator Boswell all have tried desperately to explain it to her. Unfortunately, if she is as bright as a blown globe that is not our fault, because if it ain't going in, it ain't going in, as they say in the classics.
—It's only about potential liability.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, when Democrat senators wish to zip their lips and listen, I will carry on.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)
—I suggest, Senator Knowles, that if you address your remarks through the Chair it might help, too.

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, Senator Kernot is now walking out so that she can come back in here at a later date and misrepresent Fightback again. But the interesting thing is that the Democrats want personal taxation levels increased, they want fuel tax increased—they want all taxes increased. Yet Senator Kernot is prepared to stomp out of here, not having listened to a jot of what has gone on. Of course, Senator Cook will continue to misrepresent the Fightback package out there. He, too, might have learnt something throughout this debate this afternoon if he had had the decency to listen—
—On a point of order—
—Another fallacious point of order.

—I have just been picked on, Madam Acting Deputy President, about misrepresenting the consumption tax proposal. I have never misrepresented the fact that the consumption tax proposal intends to impose a tax and increase taxes on Australians while reducing wages at the same time. I have never misrepresented that. I think the reference that I have misrepresented the proposal should be withdrawn.
—There is no point of order.

—There is certainly no point of order. Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. For Senator Cook to say that he has never misrepresented Fightback is absolutely the most barefaced thing that he could say in here—and he knows what that refers to. He simply cannot say that he does not go out, along with those Democrats who no longer want to listen, and constantly misrepresent Fightback. He constantly goes out there and says that there is going to be a 15 per cent tax on everything. The other day, for example—I think it was Sunday fortnight ago—the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, was on the
Sunday
program—
—I again raise a point of order of relevance, Madam Acting Deputy President. This matter arose because of a personal explanation from Senator Kernot.
—She's responding to your phoney point of order.
—Order!

—Senator Baume is a very polite senator! People are noting the reply. We have had about five or six people note the reply. There is tedious repetition. But the point of order is that now we are even straying from that subject. We are getting into an area in which other matters not associated with the explanation made by Senator Kernot are being canvassed. If that is the case, I will move that this matter be adjourned, and close the debate entirely. We are being lenient to allow this debate to go ahead, but if honourable senators opposite want to canvass wider issues and merge into irrelevancies, we will have the matter adjourned.

para.tab: Madam Acting Deputy President, it may suit the chamber if Senator Knowles were asked to be relevant and address what it was in the personal explanation of Senator Kernot that she finds objectionable, and then we can go on our merry way and conclude this matter reasonably. I might say that for the Government this is a great yawn because there will not be a consumption tax after all because the coalition will never get elected on that program.

talk.start.para: —I ask Senator Knowles to be careful to keep her remarks relevant.

—I will certainly do that, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am talking about the most absurd personal explanation that Senator Kernot gave, which illustrated that she has not read seven of the 700 pages of Fightback, let alone half of it or even the bit that affects her portfolio, the portfolio that she is meant to look after. That is the great tragedy. What I was saying with relevance to that is that not only does Senator Kernot misrepresent it but so does Mr Dawkins. He keeps on doing exactly what Senator Kernot has done. A fortnight ago he said that Treasury had found a $4 billion hole in Fightback. Wrong. Simply not true. Nonetheless he said it. Two days later, the Government upped the ante by $2 billion. On
AM
he said that a $6 billion hole had been found. Wrong. Simply not true. In spite of the Government's best intention, Treasury found no hole. In fact, Treasury said that the price impact would be a 3.6 per cent increase in costs, not 4.4 per cent.
—Not true.
—I have the Treasurer's press statement saying exactly that. If Senator Cook would like me to go out and get it, I will get it for him.
—Read the Treasury statements.

—If Senator Cook thinks that that is not true, I will go and get the Treasurer's press statement and, where he says that when the Government tried to blow Fightback out of the water with taxpayers' money—not your money, because governments do not have any money other than taxpayers' money—
—You are wrong in what you are saying, but what has it got to do with the personal explanation?
—I thought Senator Zakharov was in the chair, not Senator Cook.
—In that case I remind you, Senator Knowles, to address your remarks through the Chair.

—This is a bunch of untruths that is constantly being promoted by the Australian Democrats and by the Government. If one were to be generous, one could suggest that it is a shame that Senator Kernot does not understand; it is such a pity that she does not understand. But she does understand. She is intentionally misrepresenting the policy because she is trying desperately to give the Democrats some credentials as to why they are not going to do what their founder said they would do to a government—and that is to keep the bastards honest. They know that when we are elected they are going to have to find some way out of trying to stop us being faithful to our promise. This is all paving the way for it—for Senator Kernot to prove that she is not going to go ahead and allow a government to run on the promises that it has given. I think that is totally contrary to the formation of the Democrats, but that is something that they threw away a long time ago.

para.tab:
Senator Kernot has continued to back up this letter, the sheer intent of which is to mislead the farm machinery people. It says that, according to the Fightback documents, GST will be paid on all stock purchases, including all transitional stock held at the time of the introduction of the GST. I do not wish to go over the explanations that Senator Short, Senator Lewis and Senator Panizza have given, but I hope that Senator Kernot and Senator Bell, who foolishly came in and said, `Yes, it is all part of it', understand, go back and read
Hansard
and do not come into the Senate or go out into the electorate any longer spreading furphies such as this. They know the letter is incorrect and I hope, sooner or later, they will learn that some responsibility goes with being a member of parliament and part of that responsibility is to tell the truth.

talk.start.para: —Over the months we have come to expect a complete campaign of misinformation and outright untruths about the coalition's policy from the ALP—a party who promised there would be no recession, that unemployment would not reach 10 per cent and that no child would live in poverty. We have come to expect this series of continual lies and untruths. The former Prime Minister, the leader of that Party, promised the Australian public that he would lead the Party to the next election at the same time as he was making a deal with the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that he would hand over. We have come to accept those untruths and misinformation from the ALP.

para.tab: The ALP is running the most massive scare campaign in this country that we have ever seen. If it were a case of ordinary commercial advertising, the ALP would be sued for millions of dollars for damages because of the simple untruths and misrepresentations in its advertising. It is absolutely disgusting that a party that currently controls this government can be so untruthful, and so deliberately untruthful, about things when it knows the real truth.

We have come to expect this from the ALP, but we have not so far seen the same thing from the Australian Democrats. It is with some disappointment that I hear today that Senator Kernot and Senator Bell are now deliberately going out and peddling the ALP line. They are deliberately doing the misinformation trick, the untruths trick, the same as their colleagues in the ALP. I have always said that they are just an offshoot of the ALP, and they have proved more and more that that is the case. It is no wonder that the Democrats are disintegrating, that Senator Powell leaves them saying that she cannot sit with them any more, and that half of their Victorian group have left them. They have shown themselves to simply be a party of untruths which is disintegrating, and one can well understand that. The Democrats supposedly came into being to keep the other people honest. At one stage that was the point of their existence.

talk.start.para: —People swallowed that.

—People did swallow that, as Senator Parer says. That was a main plank of the Democrats' policy. Not only are they not now trying to keep people honest but also they are deliberately setting out, as the ALP is, to tell deliberate untruths, to tell deliberate misstatements about things and to say that they know better. I disagree with some of my colleagues who say that the Democrats do not understand. I think they do understand but are simply deliberately going out and telling lies to the Australian public.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)
—Order! I think the honourable senator is stepping outside parliamentary language. Will he please watch it.

talk.start.para: —Yes, Madam Acting Deputy President. It is of some sadness to me that this Party has joined the ALP so openly in telling these untruths. As I say, the people of Australia are aware of this. They see a party in absolute decline, with people leaving everywhere. There are real troubles in the New South Wales branch. I understand that in Queensland the Democrats cannot even register as a party because they do not have 500 members. There are all sorts of problems in New South Wales. Half the people in Victoria are leaving. That is all happening because the Democrats have lost their way. They have become the offshoot of the ALP, determined to push their barrow at the next Federal election. I am pleased to note that the public are noticing this and voting with their feet by leaving the Democrats in droves. That will happen more and more as the election nears.

speech.speaker: Crane Sen W.

talk.start.para: —I also rise to support my colleagues in noting the personal explanation made by Senator Kernot. I want to come straight to the substance of the letter. The third paragraph of the letter is worth repeating:

speech.para: I think you should be aware that the GST will impose a automatic tax penalty on farm machinery dealers. That is, your business will be detrimentally affected by the GST in exactly the manner that you feared would happen under the new wholesales tax regime.

That paragraph is the epitome of dirty politics. It totally misrepresents the GST as it relates to the proposed new wholesales tax regime or, for that matter, the old wholesales tax regime. It also misrepresents the total Fightback package.

para.tab: I am sorry that Senator Kernot has left this chamber because I wanted to tell her face to face about the reception I received at the Newdegate field day last week. People asked me about this particular letter that was sent out misrepresenting the facts. I am glad Senator Bell has stayed in the chamber, because on that particular night I took the letter to Senator Bell and sat next to him. If I remember correctly, Senator Bell's words were, `I cannot understand how Senator Kernot would misrepresent this because she knows better than that.' That is or words to that effect are what he said to me.

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—You can't make a personal explanation.

—I am not making a personal explanation. I am saying that Senator Crane's reliance upon his recollection of the matter is inaccurate and that he should refrain from relying on his memory in this case because it is obviously inaccurate.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)
—Order! There is no point of order.

talk.start.para: —My memory is not inaccurate. I took the letter down and showed it to Senator Bell on that particular night. It is a misrepresentation of Fightback. The Australian Democrats do not understand—and I am certain members of the Government do not understand—how machinery dealers and their businesses operate. They do not understand how they bulk buy. They do not understand the imposition of wholesale sales tax when they have to carry parts for up to 12 months. The only way machinery dealers in isolated areas can buy at a reasonable price to supply the people in those areas is to buy in bulk. With the wholesale sales tax regime, they carry the price of that right through until the day they sell. Under the GST proposal, as has already being explained—and I will not go over that—they will be rebated on the prescribed day and they will not carry the cost.

para.tab: I do not have to rely on our figures; I can go straight to the figures of the Treasury, which identified that there would be a $1 billion saving to agriculture under the Fightback package. That is another misrepresentation that is inherent in this particular letter.

The machinery dealers at Newdegate were saying to me, `The sooner we get you into government and the farmers get some money in their pockets, start turning over their machinery and doing the things they used to do the better. They will have money in their pockets'. At the same time, they recognised that under Fightback and the GST proposal their operating costs will in fact be lower. People will be better off on two counts: first, the cost structure of the machinery dealers will be lower and, secondly, the people they deal with and who provide their very existence, the farmers themselves, will be better off because they will have more money in their pockets.

It is hypocritical of the Democrats in this case to adopt the same sorts of policies that we have heard so consistently from the Australian Labor Party about the impact of Fightback on businesses. Fightback will significantly lower the cost of business in this country, particularly to machinery dealers, in a number of areas. I will not canvass all of those areas at this point in time, but it is worth noting that the removal of payroll tax, the removal of fuel excise and the removal of wholesales sales tax will allow them once again to become competitive.

If Senator Kernot is to do the decent thing, she should send another letter to the farm machinery dealers and explain to them exactly what the position is. She should show a little bit of honesty in presenting the Fightback package to the Australian public, and not be the lackey of the Labor Party and misrepresent the true position with a letter such as this.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
